[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I just want to concur with my colleague, Vice President Knight, that Stevens Towing has been a long recognized good business in this community.

[Marks]: They're always willing to step forward in the time of need when the city calls upon them.

[Marks]: And this seems to me just a way of streamlining their business.

[Marks]: And I also have no problem with this, so I would move approval as well.

[Marks]: No, I'm good, thank you.

[Marks]: You're good, you're good.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I'm kind of taken back.

[Marks]: They're not in phase one.

[Marks]: Yeah, we're in those discussions, and we will.

[Marks]: I think my colleague, Councilor Knight, made a great explanation of what this is trying to accomplish.

[Marks]: And many of the crucial pieces of legislation that we put forth require three readings.

[Marks]: And I think what Councilor Knight is getting at, a public hearing is really no difference than any other important document we work on.

[Marks]: And what happens in a city ordinance, the first reading is what appears on the agenda.

[Marks]: So a public hearing appears on the agenda for the first time.

[Marks]: The difference between the public hearing and the three readings is the three readings then require you to put notice in the newspaper, then require you to come back for a third reading for final approval.

[Marks]: None of that takes place during a public hearing.

[Marks]: So my colleagues write.

[Marks]: What typically happens is we'll listen, we'll hear both sides, and then typically act.

[Marks]: So I agree with 90% of this language.

[Marks]: I'm not sure.

[Marks]: The six-day calendar day, I think we can debate about that.

[Marks]: But there has to be a grace period, which allows for public comments.

[Marks]: And I agree with that.

[Marks]: Public comments can also be put forth ahead of time

[Marks]: However, if you're not aware of what the petition is going after until that meeting happens, then how do you make a comment on something you're not aware of?

[Marks]: And there may not be enough information that's presented on the council agenda or so forth to make an informed decision.

[Marks]: So I have no problem with that.

[Marks]: It's very important during this process.

[Marks]: Mr. President, I think it was about four years ago this council voted for the only TIF that I can recall with Bianco Sausage.

[Marks]: And at the time, Mr. President, their commitment to this city was to add 20 new full-time jobs.

[Marks]: And now we're looking at a commitment of 250 jobs.

[Marks]: So I see this as a real job growth and economic recovery.

[Marks]: revitalizer, which I think will be good for the area.

[Marks]: And I agree with my colleagues regarding living wages and so forth.

[Marks]: And I'm sure we could probably work towards that, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The questions that I raised last week, I still have this week, Mr. President, and I'm going to propose them again.

[Marks]: And I'm not sure if we've had any time to work on some of this, but I really would like to try to pin down the potential trucking routes

[Marks]: to this establishment, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I know we're talking about increasing business there from what currently exists.

[Marks]: And I think it's important for those of us that actually surround this, there are neighborhoods around this facility.

[Marks]: I realize this is a commercial area.

[Marks]: But it's embedded in a residential neighborhood, both the Haines Square and the Wellington neighborhood with many residents.

[Marks]: So I would like to find out from maybe Mr. Moniker if he's had the ability to respond to the question that I asked last week of what potential truck routes they will be looking at, knowing that two of the major roads that exist around this area don't allow major trucking.

[Marks]: So in my opinion, that would disperse trucks on some of the secondary roads, and I have a concern.

[Marks]: So that would be my first question, Mr. President, regarding the truck routes.

[Marks]: And if Mr. Monica has had the opportunity to look into it, if not, I think it's something that still requires a response, Mr. President, to this council.

[Marks]: Okay, I appreciate you looking into that and I thank you for your response.

[Marks]: The other question I had was, you mentioned originally that Monogram was going to open as two shifts with the potential of a third shift.

[Marks]: I know at this point you probably can't commit, but I have a concern about a potential third shift.

[Marks]: And I was wondering if a third shift would require the extended hours for any business, and would that be a vote of the council?

[Marks]: This, I don't think, is a question for Mr. Modica, but I don't know who else we have on the call.

[Marks]: Do we have Commissioner Moki or anyone else on the call?

[Marks]: Mr. President, I want to thank Councilor Knight for bringing that up.

[Marks]: That was helpful.

[Marks]: So Mr. President, knowing that this would require a special permit of the council, I think eases some of the concern I have regarding a third shift.

[Marks]: I'm not saying I'm opposed to a third shift.

[Marks]: I realize that the previous business, I believe, did have a third shift, an active third shift there.

[Marks]: But that eases some of my concerns of residents that I spoke to regarding potential trucking at 1, 2, 3 in the morning.

[Marks]: And we all know when 18 wheelers go by your house and hit the many potholes we have on our roads and the many divots we have, that it shakes homes and so forth, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So that's comforting to know.

[Marks]: My third point, Mr. President, and I brought this up last week, and it's a major concern, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Middlesex Ave, and I don't have to tell anyone behind this reel, is a disgrace.

[Marks]: The sidewalk, the road, the lighting, everything on that road is a complete and utter disgrace.

[Marks]: And that's no lie.

[Marks]: sit and meet with the State Department of Transportation, Mr. President, and put together a full-fledged plan.

[Marks]: And it is that road, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Any corporate decision.

[Marks]: Yeah, not corporate, any corporate decision.

[Marks]: Corporate decision.

[Marks]: To change, yeah.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President, and I appreciate the comments by Mr. Navar that regarding the residential factor.

[Marks]: And some of what he mentioned, if not all, is completely on track.

[Marks]: that we heard tonight from the city assessor that Method is a desirable community because we have such a low residential tax rate.

[Marks]: And therefore, people want to come into the community and buy property because we have such a great low tax rate.

[Marks]: And on the flip side, Mr. President, commercial business may not see fit to come to our community because of the extremely aggressive and high tax rate.

[Marks]: And when we do the split rate, which we've been doing for years, we've always shifted, and I voted for it, we've always shifted the burden from the residents to commercial, saying, well, they're a commercial business and they should pay more in the community.

[Marks]: And I agree with that, Mr. President, but I think you get it to a point where

[Marks]: The burden on the commercial, Mr. President, is having an impact on the community.

[Marks]: And when you see the percent of property in our community by value by class, almost 90% of the percent of levy

[Marks]: that we derive from our income is for residential property, 90%.

[Marks]: And then the commercial industrial make up 8.72%.

[Marks]: So you can see over the years, the shift, we're losing a lot of the commercial base, which we rely on now because they pay a much higher tax rate and we're gaining more residential, which pays a lower.

[Marks]: And at some point, we as a community are going to make a tough decision and say we don't have enough of this commercial that we've been shifting the burden to, to support our budget.

[Marks]: And I think that's going to be the question, Mr. President, that we're going to have to answer to eventually.

[Marks]: And I think it's creeping around sooner than we expect, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The numbers, if you look at the single tax rate, which we haven't supported since I've been on the council.

[Marks]: If you look at the single tax rate, so that would be one tax rate for both commercial and residential, an average single family would pay $6,326.

[Marks]: And the average commercial business would pay $14,707.

[Marks]: So that's with one tax rate for both sides.

[Marks]: Then you look at it, Mr. President, and if you were going to do a split rate, which we currently do, at 115%, the average single family would pay $6,215 and the average commercial would pay $6,915.

[Marks]: Then if you fast forward that into what we currently do is a split rate with 175% shift.

[Marks]: The average single family pays 5,768, so you can see it's decreased.

[Marks]: And the average commercial pays 25,737.

[Marks]: So they went with the single tax rate from 14,000 for commercial up to 25,000.

[Marks]: And then if you split the rate at 115%, they went from 16,000 to 25,000.

[Marks]: Those are huge jumps, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And if you look at, if we were to reverse this a little bit and look at shifting the burden to residential, the average single family at 175, at the single family rate,

[Marks]: The single rate would pay $6,000, and at the split rate would pay $6,215.

[Marks]: The difference, really, if we sat down and started going through this, because you're shifting it over so many different properties, it's not as big as the commercial side.

[Marks]: And I know it's not a popular thing to say, but if we're really serious about keeping commercial in this city, Mr. President, and expanding the commercial tax base,

[Marks]: I think we have to take a look at it at some point.

[Marks]: And sometimes, you know, officials have to stand up and take tough votes, Mr. President.

[Marks]: But I think it's something we have to look at.

[Marks]: And, you know, it's probably not going to be this time, but I think next year I would request, Mr. President,

[Marks]: that we have meetings a month or two prior to the budget meeting.

[Marks]: I'm sorry, the tax vote meeting.

[Marks]: So we could start looking at the residential factor.

[Marks]: So we could start looking at the residential exemption that has been discussed about by area residents, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And give us enough lead time to make some informed decisions rather than tonight, which most of us, to be quite honest with you,

[Marks]: I hate to say it, our hands are tied, because this is based on the budget that we put forward and it is what it is.

[Marks]: So I would ask Mr. President, under the leadership of yourself or whoever, as the Council of Vice President, Kaviel's the next president, that we have meetings well in advance.

[Marks]: to when we set the tax rate so we can discuss some of the issues, Mr. President.

[Marks]: As we heard tonight, I always thought that the tax rate was due at the end of January.

[Marks]: We heard that you could vote on it to have it done at the end of June, which gives you another six months of additional

[Marks]: growth that you could use in a time of recession like we're seeing now.

[Marks]: That's six months that could add some new growth onto it and give us some additional revenue.

[Marks]: And that's the lead time I think we need as a council to start discussing this.

[Marks]: I'm prepared to vote on this tonight, Mr. President, but I think, you know, we have to take a long, hard look at how we average out the property in our community and see if it makes sense to continue to shift the way we're shifting if we're really serious about keeping a commercial base in this community.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Second.

[Marks]: Mr. President, before you call the roll.

[Marks]: I just wanted to clarify that last year when we discussed the residential exemption, and I know Mr. Castagnetti has been a stalwart regarding this.

[Marks]: He says 10 years, I think he's been talking about this for 20 years, or at least it seems 20 years.

[Marks]: So long, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Last year when we discussed it, I think Councilor Knight brought up the fact that the numbers that we received that were the break even point for assessments over, I think it was 640,000 Councilor Knight mentioned, was a little over 2,000 households that were owner occupied, that lived in their home.

[Marks]: If we voted for residential exemption, because their property was assessed at over a certain amount of money, which was the break even point, they would still have to pay a higher tax rate.

[Marks]: And we were told there were about 2,000 properties in the community, that was last year.

[Marks]: And that's a number I've been monitoring over the years, because I think we as a council, I won't speak for anyone else, said if the numbers were falling, meaning that there were less and less people that fell in this range.

[Marks]: that were the exception to the rule that we may see favorable to vote on this and provide a property tax, a residential exemption.

[Marks]: We heard tonight, Mr. President, from the city assessor that they're saying now there's over 4,000 properties that are above the break even point, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And in addition, out of the 4,000, 1,300 properties of people that are over the age of 60, which are seniors in our community.

[Marks]: So these numbers are very staggering, Mr. President, and there may have been a discrepancy over the years.

[Marks]: As we heard from the city's assessor, and I won't put words in her mouth, that they may have not been counting every type of property.

[Marks]: So they may have been just looking at single families and not condos or two families or multi-families.

[Marks]: actually taking a closer look at this and seeing if these are the true numbers.

[Marks]: I think the city assessor made a commitment that she would revisit these numbers to see if they're true and accurate.

[Marks]: And in this case, they fluctuated in a way that

[Marks]: I couldn't support at this particular point.

[Marks]: We're asking over and above.

[Marks]: We're not asking to restore the way it was.

[Marks]: That's how every project is done.

[Marks]: So I'm not, I think our definition is a little different, Mr. President.

[Marks]: This council did a committee, the whole review of the lot of land in between Budweiser and the residents on Sydney Street.

[Marks]: It was all overgrown, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The trees, we took a walk through that whole area and it was gnarly back there and very dangerous actually.

[Marks]: And due to this council and the city administration with their help, Budweiser actually, because they own the property, went back there and did actually, I have to say, a great job of cleaning up.

[Marks]: They left a lot of the mature trees along the fences of neighbors on Sydney, of which they did go out recently and cut some of them.

[Marks]: 84 Sydney just contacted me and said there's a big overhanging branch of a very mature tree that's on the Anheuser Budweiser.

[Marks]: and they ask in the interest of public safety, because they're concerned with the recent windstorms, that the branches be cut back in the interest of public safety.

[Marks]: So I ask that this be sent to DPW and the city engineer's office.

[Marks]: I believe they're the ones that intervened last time on our behalf.

[Marks]: Is this for take-out only or is it for dine-in take-out?

[Marks]: Good question.

[Marks]: I'm not quite sure what this applies to.

[Marks]: I just want to understand.

[Marks]: I think Councilor Bears said this would be for guidance.

[Marks]: However, it's asking the Board of Health and the Office of Energy and Environment to establish a policy.

[Marks]: Most policies will have some type of enforcement

[Marks]: with the policy.

[Marks]: So do you anticipate an enforcement onto this policy, or is it guidance?

[Marks]: Because they're two completely different things.

[Marks]: Well, I'm not sure, Mr. President, if we currently don't have enough resources, why would we add on another administrative responsibility if we don't have enough resources right now to control what we have?

[Marks]: I just don't know what this is getting at, Mr. President.

[Marks]: If I'm at work and I order a cup of soup and it arrives and there's no spoon, that's a concern, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I guess we take for granted that a restaurant, if I'm doing takeout, is going to put the necessary things in the bag so I can consume my food.

[Marks]: And part of that may be a straw, a napkin, whatever it might be.

[Marks]: And so I'm not quite sure what this is getting at.

[Marks]: Is this COVID related or is this outside of COVID?

[Marks]: I don't know what this is getting at.

[Marks]: Mr. President.

[Marks]: Just if I could, I'm a little confused.

[Marks]: If it's something we can't enforce, then why are we asking to a border health and the energy environment office to establish a policy?

[Marks]: If it's something we can't enforce and then only to only provide plastic utensils upon request.

[Marks]: So you're asking businesses,

[Marks]: not to provide this unless someone asks you.

[Marks]: and I assume a policy, you know, to me, the better approach would be if this is a cause and something you're interested in, why not approach the Chamber of Commerce and ask the Chamber of Commerce, hey, you know what, we're concerned about the plastic utensils and the number of utensils that are given out and I share a lot of those concerns.

[Marks]: But I'm not sure a legislative enactment or a policy has to be the way to go about getting the word out in the community.

[Marks]: You may have businesses owners that would love to save money, because they're very expensive, by the way.

[Marks]: And they may love to save money on that, but I'm not sure this is the appropriate way of doing this, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And we heard for a long period of time about doing away with straws.

[Marks]: Now it's stirrers, plastic utensils.

[Marks]: But Mr. President, the reason why I bring this up is he made a recommendation of this council and also for our state and federal delegation.

[Marks]: And I want to make sure, because this council has been on top of this issue for many years now,

[Marks]: back in 2010, and then back in 2016 when the MIT study was initiated to look at departure and arrival procedures at Logan Airport.

[Marks]: And how to more equitably find solutions to dispersing flight traffic over the city of Medford.

[Marks]: As was stated in my resolution on August 14th, 2020, the North Regional Administrator for the FAA,

[Marks]: sent a letter to Massport Community Advisory Committee stating that they were no longer going to look at the dispersion proposals that came out of the MIT study.

[Marks]: So that was a big hit to us as a community, because we were really counting on having at least someone from the FAA consider how to ease up and disperse some of the flights that are impacting our community so daily.

[Marks]: On October 15th, the leaderships in Method, Cambridge, Arlington, and Malden responded to the FAA, their feasibility assessment with a request back to the FAA to earnestly and promptly apply the considerable resources at its disposal to propose an alternative departure procedure for runway 33L that would disperse jet noise more equitably.

[Marks]: So that was sent out on behalf of the four communities, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Then on October 21st, six members of the federal delegation sent a letter to the FAA regional administrator reinforcing the October 15th letter sent by the municipalities and their proposed ideas to reduce overflight noise over the city of Medford and the surrounding communities.

[Marks]: So I just ask, Mr. President, in follow up to the response that we received from Peter Hulk, dated November 16th, 2020, that we request that our state and federal delegation commit to reinforce the message.

[Marks]: That noise concentration has created permanent problem that will not go away until the FAA addresses the problem with a procedure change.

[Marks]: So I would ask that we send that to our local delegation as well as our federal delegation, Mr. President, asking that they keep up the request to make sure that the FAA and Massport realize

[Marks]: that this is considerable noise, pollution, and destruction to the quality of life for area residents, and that we stay on top of the issue, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I appreciate, once again, our representatives on the MCAC for their due diligence, Mr. President, and their foresight on this issue.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I want to thank you for setting up that meeting and inviting all the city players to the table.

[Marks]: It was a great meeting and my council colleagues couldn't ask better questions to get results on behalf of the neighborhood.

[Marks]: I would just ask that we do set up the follow-up meeting because that was our commitment.

[Marks]: to the neighborhood and also I know we met at the corner of Fulton Spring and Fern, but there were a number of other hotspot areas going up Fulton Spring Road that also need to be addressed.

[Marks]: And I'm hoping that on this next meeting, we can start picking away little by little on some of the other areas and staying on top of them.

[Marks]: And I just want to thank my colleagues for taking a Saturday out and going down there and thank the residents for coming out.

[Marks]: I firmly believe we have to do more of that because I think it's a good way.

[Marks]: We can talk and talk and talk.

[Marks]: It's a good way of getting issues addressed.

[Marks]: We bring the department heads and actually witness firsthand what's going on.

[Marks]: How many cars do we see roll through that four way stop?

[Marks]: Many, we could have given out 100 tickets.

[Marks]: Mr. President, it was really, it was a dangerous area, but we slowed them down.

[Marks]: There were so many of us, we actually slowed them down, but I think it shows you what's happening in our community, in every neighborhood of this community.

[Marks]: So I thank you for your leadership, Mr. President, and look forward to the upcoming meeting.

[Marks]: Mr. President.

[Marks]: Yes, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: I would just ask that the entire council be named on both those papers.

[Marks]: Okay.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: This truly is a big loss for the community.

[Marks]: You know, Sandy was one of the first people I met in public office back some 26 years ago.

[Marks]: And you couldn't meet a kinder, gentler person that just, for many years she served as the Program Administrator for the Early Child Care Program within the Medford Public Schools.

[Marks]: She was just a sweetheart of a person.

[Marks]: She was devoted to her family and friends, a truly loving mother, wife, sister.

[Marks]: And what I didn't know about Sandy, and she was a woman of many talents, she was an accomplished and published poet, which I never knew.

[Marks]: And she was an accomplished world traveler.

[Marks]: And, you know, she really is,

[Marks]: There's going to be a hole in this community that's missing, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Because when you lose someone of that character, someone of that stature, someone that put kids first, I don't know if you can recover from that.

[Marks]: And I just want to, on behalf of the city council, wish her family well and her husband Rick, who we all know.

[Marks]: I wish him well, Mr. President, in this very difficult time.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: For those that have been around this city for a number of years, Ralph Surrett was our faithful cameraman for a lot of years in this corner room.

[Marks]: You probably never saw him because he was very behind the scenes, never wanted any public light, was truly a kind, gentle man when you talk to him.

[Marks]: He'd always tell you about what's going on in local news and he was a real animal lover and someone that was an advocate for animals within this community and a graduate of the Medford Vocational School and someone that

[Marks]: was a true Methodite for a lot of years, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Councilor Marks?

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I put this on the agenda, Mr. President, it's been some time now since this council has approved municipal aggregation.

[Marks]: I've received a number of calls from residents that are pleased with the aggregation and other residents that are questioning why their bills are so high.

[Marks]: So I thought it was only appropriate now that we revisit the program.

[Marks]: see how the program is running, Mr. President, see if there's anything needed, maybe to update residents of this community, or if there's anything we can do as a community to improve the program.

[Marks]: So I believe we have Alicia Hunt on the phone.

[Marks]: Yes, she is.

[Marks]: On the Zoom.

[Marks]: So at this time, Mr. President, I will yield to Alicia.

[Marks]: Mr. President.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I want to thank Alicia for her presentation.

[Marks]: That was very helpful.

[Marks]: I would ask that while this program goes forward, that we receive quarterly updates.

[Marks]: I think that would be extremely helpful.

[Marks]: Alicia, my question to you is, just so we're comparing apples with apples.

[Marks]: I'm trying to compare someone that opted out of the program, that stayed on National Grid, compared to if they were to go on to the program for the same period of time with DiEnergy.

[Marks]: And you're saying to me the average difference over a period of time is $0.04?

[Marks]: Okay.

[Marks]: So, so that's an average.

[Marks]: So, so that's an average.

[Marks]: So naturally there are some residents that paid less than $4.

[Marks]: And some that paid more than four.

[Marks]: Do we know how much more than four?

[Marks]: So just fill me in because it's been some time, Alicia.

[Marks]: If I opted out of the program and someone that's currently in the program wants to go back and forth, how easy is it to go back and forth, opt in and opt out of the program?

[Marks]: Right, so from what you're telling me, that was going to be my other question.

[Marks]: As a community, we're not allowed to advise our residents as you just stated.

[Marks]: You said, jeez, if everyone's in the program now, I would ask you to stay in the program because the contractor's rates are going to be far better than national grid's rates.

[Marks]: So what you did was just advise people to stay in.

[Marks]: And you're saying that's something that we really shouldn't be doing as a community?

[Marks]: So how would one, when you say, look at these differences, I realize you're showing us the presentation now.

[Marks]: How would one know this to actually take advantage?

[Marks]: Right.

[Marks]: Do we provide a chart similar to this?

[Marks]: So do you think we would be in violation if we were to share this particular graph with residents?

[Marks]: Right, and the reason why I say it is, and the reason why I think it's important to give quarterly updates, is that we have consultants that are working on this.

[Marks]: And why not be able to benefit from their knowledge to spread that out to the community to allow them to make an informed decision whether they want to come and go from a program.

[Marks]: And I can appreciate the fact that our numbers are based on enrollment, right?

[Marks]: Because if the numbers drop too low, we're probably not going to get the same rate, correct?

[Marks]: Right.

[Marks]: So for the time being, I didn't know we were locked in until 2022.

[Marks]: And it doesn't matter.

[Marks]: Enrollment doesn't matter for that period of time, which is great news for us, because there's no bottom line on that.

[Marks]: So my question again is, why aren't we promoting this as a program to show when the best time to get on and off the program is?

[Marks]: You're saying we can't do that legally?

[Marks]: So when you say that number, how does that compare to prior to aggregation?

[Marks]: Because anyone could have opted for green options prior to aggregation, correct?

[Marks]: I didn't quite question council.

[Marks]: So you mentioned 3.6 million, correct?

[Marks]: That's correct.

[Marks]: And that's what you said.

[Marks]: Additional 3.6 million with aggregation.

[Marks]: Prior to aggregation, where were we as a community?

[Marks]: Do we know those numbers?

[Marks]: Well, just if I could, so prior to municipal aggregation, I'm under the impression that people were allowed to get additional green energy if they opted to.

[Marks]: So before municipal energy came into, aggregation came into the community, there were people buying green energy.

[Marks]: Is that not correct?

[Marks]: Okay.

[Marks]: And we don't know what that figure was then in our community.

[Marks]: So, Mr. President, I'd like to make a motion at this point that the city

[Marks]: interact with our rate payers.

[Marks]: And our city provide information relative to, like we've seen the chart tonight, relative to where the market is and where the rates are over a given span of time.

[Marks]: So people are allowed to make informed decisions, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I would ask that that be part of the website and part of any type of outreach.

[Marks]: I have yet to see any outreach since December 2019.

[Marks]: It's not to say it hasn't happened, but I have yet to see any outreach letting the community know where we stand with municipal aggregation.

[Marks]: This was a very large endeavor when we instituted this.

[Marks]: And I find it ironic that

[Marks]: You need a buy-in into the program, right?

[Marks]: They're saying, well, look how many of these people signed up for the program.

[Marks]: But this was an opt.

[Marks]: You had to opt out of the program, so everyone was automatically opt into the program.

[Marks]: So if it wasn't for the legislation that allowed for that, Mr. President, the numbers may not be this large.

[Marks]: So I think the program started off with the ability to have everyone automatically enrolled and then those that wanted to get out of it, which is a little different than

[Marks]: the way I would personally handle it, but that's how the state legislature decided to implement this program.

[Marks]: So they can make informed decisions when they want to opt in and opt out.

[Marks]: I can see that with people coming in and out of it towards the end of the contract.

[Marks]: It doesn't seem to me that that would be

[Marks]: a violation of the contract, just updating our residents and alerting them when the best time to be on municipal aggregation in the interest of their pocketbook.

[Marks]: There's a need in the community to have someone coordinate our elections, Mr. President.

[Marks]: We've been very fortunate to have a great staff and a clerk that oversees the process.

[Marks]: And our voting rolls have increased over the last number of years, I believe by almost 10,000 new voters in this community.

[Marks]: That in my opinion, and I'd like to hear from the city clerk, that this position is well warranted within this community.

[Marks]: And I think we should get all the stakeholders, I agree, at the table.

[Marks]: However, Mr. President, this is two years now.

[Marks]: And if we can arrive at some type of time frame, Mr. President,

[Marks]: I will give it my support tonight.

[Marks]: If not, Mr. President, I am tired of lip service.

[Marks]: Not to say that that's the case here, but I am tired of lip service.

[Marks]: And I want to see action, especially on such an important position in this community, Mr. President.

[Marks]: If we can't guarantee to residents in this community that we can have a fair election, Mr. President, and an election that we know is

[Marks]: On the utmost regarding security safety, then we're not doing what we were supposed to be doing as elected officials.

[Marks]: And I believe having this position would secure that, Mr. President, and it would secure us for a number of years moving forward as we see elections changing, not only in Method, but across the nation.

[Marks]: So at this point, I'd like to ask the city clerk, because this is not something we just want to create a position on.

[Marks]: This is something that's needed.

[Marks]: And I'd like to hear from the chief election officer in the community that's been overseeing the process for the last two years, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Can you just speak to the particular need?

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. Clerk, and if I could just follow up, Mr. President.

[Marks]: It's my understanding, and I think I mentioned this last week, that some many years ago, there used to be two separate positions.

[Marks]: It was the city clerk position and elections coordinator position that existed.

[Marks]: The person in the election coordinator position, from my understanding, retired.

[Marks]: And rather than looking for another election coordinator position, the city clerk took it on as a stipend position.

[Marks]: And that's where we fell for many years.

[Marks]: And I can guarantee you in all the surrounding communities that the city clerk is not the person that's in charge or coordinates the elections in all the surrounding communities.

[Marks]: That is a separate and distinct function and role and separate person.

[Marks]: And I think we're at a point right now in this community and the size of this community that this is warranted.

[Marks]: I don't believe anyone in the administration doesn't believe so either.

[Marks]: But I want to make sure, Mr. President, that we're not here another year from now talking about the same issue and putting our resources into the same things over and over again.

[Marks]: So that's why I'm hoping if we can get a commitment tonight on when we will see this position, I'll give the administration all the needed time they need to meet with the stakeholders and parties and draft the job description and so forth.

[Marks]: But we need a time frame, Mr. President, that someone will be in that position.

[Marks]: And that's how I will vote for this tonight.

[Marks]: No, I understand that.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And this paper was on the agenda a week ago, and we sent back last Tuesday a message to the administration, and I believe the chief of staff was on the meeting last week with this council's intent.

[Marks]: And to come back and say that he has no authority to make any decisions as the chief of staff, I think falls short of the mark, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Because clearly the council made it known what our intent was last week.

[Marks]: And I agree with Councilor Knight, however, the paper was presented the way it was presented.

[Marks]: I don't think we can go through this and pick and choose what items we'd like to move forward with and what items we'd like to sit on.

[Marks]: I don't believe we can do that.

[Marks]: If the administration wants to recall this,

[Marks]: paper and then submit another paper that we can agree upon.

[Marks]: Ideally, Mr. President, it would have been nice for the administration maybe to sit down in a committee of the whole at the council and say, hey, look, we have $740,000.

[Marks]: These are the things we'd like to do in the community.

[Marks]: What are your thoughts?

[Marks]: Right?

[Marks]: That didn't happen, and so be it, Mr. President.

[Marks]: But clearly, I am not going to commit because the administration's unwilling to commit.

[Marks]: Because from what I'm hearing tonight, there is no commitment.

[Marks]: You can wait your 45 days.

[Marks]: They can come out with ten different job descriptions.

[Marks]: There's still no commitment to fund this position, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And just because they come out with a job description doesn't make me feel warm and fuzzy that that's a commitment.

[Marks]: That is not a commitment, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Been around a long time, and that is not a formal commitment.

[Marks]: And I think we heard that here tonight.

[Marks]: So as we stated before, if the council feels this is necessary, Mr. President, we stand up, send the paper back.

[Marks]: So if that's the will of the council, I will follow that, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Councilor Marks, would you like to- Thank you, Mr. President, and I appreciate the representative from National Grid being on the call again tonight.

[Marks]: The question I think which was supported by this council, Mr. President, was to have Diana go back to National Grid regarding putting together some mitigation to address curbing in the area of Riverside Ave that this construction work was going to be done.

[Marks]: I think the total construction paving and marking, according to the representative from National Grid, was about $400,000.

[Marks]: We by no means were looking for mitigation to that level.

[Marks]: However, we were looking to address the lack of the appropriate height of curbing on Riverside Ave, which currently right now is level with the street and very dangerous to pedestrians.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President, and I want to thank my two colleagues for putting this on.

[Marks]: This was a real big shock, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Leo was always very spunky.

[Marks]: He'd be the first to give a good word and also tell you the truth on something, too.

[Marks]: But regarding some of these positions, there's been long discussion, not just this particular year with the election.

[Marks]: that the elections department just went through, but for the past several years, this city has requested an election coordinator.

[Marks]: We currently don't have someone that coordinates our elections.

[Marks]: We do have a city clerk that wears multiple hats, but he is not an elections coordinator.

[Marks]: And all the surrounding cities and towns that I looked into have that position.

[Marks]: And for some reason, the city of Medford, with a city of almost 60,000 people and 41,000 registered voters, we don't have someone that coordinates our elections.

[Marks]: And I think that's a shortfall in this community.

[Marks]: And with everything going on nationally, that it's very important that

[Marks]: We have someone that can make sure the integrity of our election is what everyone would come to expect.

[Marks]: So have we looked into, I know this council has put forward several, and I know I've put forward a couple, and I know my colleagues have, several requests for the city administration to hire an elections coordinator.

[Marks]: I believe the mayor has sat down and has discussed the issue.

[Marks]: Can you give us an update?

[Marks]: where we stand with an election coordinator, and why it's not part of this list here.

[Marks]: Right, but those are one-time funds, and I'm talking about a long-term plan in the community to have oversight within a very important department.

[Marks]: And I think when this list that we're going to go over soon that was presented to us, this is to help the city move forward on some shortfalls that we have.

[Marks]: or shortcomings, I should say, in how we operate city government.

[Marks]: Does anyone behind this reel know of or read or aware of this comprehensive traffic study?

[Marks]: That may have been part of the study, and Officer Brooks does a great job.

[Marks]: But Mr. President, I'm not aware of any comprehensive traffic study that resulted from this council's request over and over again.

[Marks]: And it's quite troubling when you have area residents that call you up and say, whatever resulted with the meetings that we had at St.

[Marks]: Francis?

[Marks]: Whatever resulted with the traffic commission that was going to look into speeding cars and cut through traffic?

[Marks]: Whatever resulted from the additional signage that we spoke about on Fulton Spring Road, Fels Ave, Murray Hill Road, Fels Ave Terrace, that particular corridor, Mr. President?

[Marks]: which is still a bone of contention for many, many area residents.

[Marks]: I don't have to tell you that, Mr. President.

[Marks]: You're well aware of the concerns and have fought just as hard to get something done in that particular area, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I had a resident call me the other day.

[Marks]: It said, we as residents were concerned about a four-way stop at Rockland Road, Fels Ave, and Fels Ave Terrace.

[Marks]: And they asked for a four-way stop.

[Marks]: They were told by someone within the police department or the traffic division, well, what you need to do first is get together a petition.

[Marks]: Then you're going to get more than 50% of the area residents to sign the petition.

[Marks]: And we'll entertain it with the traffic commission to put up a four-way stop.

[Marks]: And I'm thinking to myself, Mr-.

[Marks]: That's an excellent point.

[Marks]: I'm not sure what that process was, but I can tell you, Mr. President, it's one thing to say that you're looking to get resident permit parking on a street and to see if there's a buy-in from the area residents.

[Marks]: I can see that, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I may not agree with having someone go out and do the legwork, but I can see why that's done.

[Marks]: But to get basic signage regarding four-way stops, Mr. President, there should not be a need of area residents to get together, sign petitions, do the legwork.

[Marks]: It makes absolutely no sense, Mr. President.

[Marks]: That should be an issue that's presented before the Traffic Commission and let them do their homework.

[Marks]: No reflection on the traffic commission, but I've stated this for years as a member of the council.

[Marks]: We used to have a traffic commission and then an off-street parking commission in the city.

[Marks]: And people would say, how do I get this done?

[Marks]: Well, I'm not sure, you may have to go to the off-street parking commission or the traffic commission, maybe they don't handle that particular item.

[Marks]: We finally merged both back some years ago.

[Marks]: We finally merged them together, so it's one stop shopping.

[Marks]: However, Mr. President,

[Marks]: I hate to say it, but the chief of police in his capacity with a department of over 100 people in a major city is also the chair of the traffic commission.

[Marks]: And in my opinion, no reflection, I know many of the members and they do great work.

[Marks]: It's a reactionary body.

[Marks]: They don't go out looking to make improvements, Mr. President.

[Marks]: They just wait for stuff to come to them.

[Marks]: And I think it's long overdue that we look how we operate the rules and regulations and how our traffic commission operates, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Because it's too much of a process to get quick turnaround and things to happen quick in the city.

[Marks]: Because you may get something through the traffic commission, but it may take you eight months to get the sign.

[Marks]: Erect it.

[Marks]: It's just an issue, Mr. President, that needs to be attended to.

[Marks]: And like I said, I hope I don't offend anyone, but when you see something that needs to be attended to, after so many years, the traffic commission's created by, I believe, the state legislature.

[Marks]: It was a home rule petition that creates the traffic commission and so forth.

[Marks]: It needs to be looked at.

[Marks]: It possibly needs to be revisited.

[Marks]: A couple of the concerns I had with area residents.

[Marks]: If this work is going on, just say, in December and January, and when it's 10 below, to have your heat off for five, six hours could be a problem.

[Marks]: November 15 is towards the end of December, beginning of January.

[Marks]: I happen to live right off of Riverside Ave.

[Marks]: And many of the curbs

[Marks]: a level with the street.

[Marks]: So there's no distinction between a sidewalk and the street.

[Marks]: They've become level.

[Marks]: Thank God no one was there.

[Marks]: And it demolished brick and cement stairs.

[Marks]: It says the scope of the MWRA section 57 project includes resurfacing and striping this portion of Riverside Ave.

[Marks]: So they're saying the MWRA is responsible for the resurfacing and restriping.

[Marks]: If they're going to grind it up or whatever they're going to do, we have to make these curbs full curbing.

[Marks]: And now's the time to do it.

[Marks]: So they're saying, we realize MWRE is going to do the paving.

[Marks]: We're doing the job, but they're going to pay for the paving.

[Marks]: And instead of us being responsible for something, we'll do some work somewhere else.

[Marks]: So I don't agree with this condition 12.

[Marks]: This money should be spent on Riverside Ave.

[Marks]: It should bring those curbs up to the current standards, the safety guidelines and highway standards of DOT.

[Marks]: which I can guarantee you level curbs with streets are not the safety standard of DOT.

[Marks]: in the DPW public works building that held most of the plans of our engineering.

[Marks]: And many of the plans were lost.

[Marks]: And from what I'm being told, the plans and the drawings for the underground utilities at the corner of Riverside and Locust Street are no longer around.

[Marks]: So you can't find these plans because they were burnt in the fire.

[Marks]: And now would be a perfect time if they're going to be digging up that area, which they are, would be a perfect time to recreate these drawings and digitize the underground utilities in that area.

[Marks]: That would save us a heartache, Mr. President, and also get the work done on behalf.

[Marks]: And I raise this question because when they were working on Wegmans and the project on Locust Street, there were many questions raised about underground utilities, and the city of Medford could not produce these plants.

[Marks]: So I would ask that as a second recommendation, that at the corner of Riverside and Locust Street,

[Marks]: that during this project that the city recreate the drawings and digitize underground utilities at that particular location in the interest of our public safety and our community.

[Marks]: So I would ask that that be part of a condition on this report.

[Marks]: Especially now we're adding 400 and I believe it's 50 units in that area of new housing.

[Marks]: And we have the Wegmans, which is very busy.

[Marks]: Very accurate.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Oh, I don't want to table right now.

[Marks]: This is a very important road, length of road in our community.

[Marks]: Mr. Engineer, my question is, I actually had three questions, but as you know, the curbing on Riverside Ave for the most part is level with the street.

[Marks]: And I was wondering what your thoughts are if we are going to do a paving and a re-striping and so forth.

[Marks]: why we wouldn't be addressing, at least within this stretch, the restoration of the curbing and reestablish it as a true curb and not something that's level with the street.

[Marks]: Right, so as part of

[Marks]: Number 12, Tim, it says that the MWRA section 57 project includes resurfacing and striping of this portion of Riverside Ave.

[Marks]: And then it goes on to say the engineering division requests that National Grid contribute to the cost of a final restoration to other paving in the city.

[Marks]: So it seems to me that we could ask of National Grid to step up and look at some of our curbing conditions, but rather the condition in here states we'll look at them to do other projects in the city.

[Marks]: And what I'm saying is right now, I don't believe that the current condition of that curbing on most of Riverside Ave meets any safety standard of DOT.

[Marks]: I can't see how a level curb that meets the street meets any requirement of safety standard.

[Marks]: Right, right.

[Marks]: So what I'll do different, and this is no reflection on you, because you're relatively new in terms of this city, is that I've been hearing about Riverside Avenue curbing for a number of years, a lot of years.

[Marks]: And now we have an opportunity where we have the MWRA and we have National Grid doing a fairly major project.

[Marks]: And we're asking to resurface a street that we already know has some potential safety issues, i.e.

[Marks]: the curbing.

[Marks]: And we're not going to address it at this point.

[Marks]: We're going to kind of kick the can down the street again.

[Marks]: And I appreciate the fact that this may be much larger than the scope.

[Marks]: But I think at this point, I assume they're going to be grinding the entire street down?

[Marks]: Right.

[Marks]: So why not take this opportunity to call upon National Grid and the MWRA to step up

[Marks]: and do this work.

[Marks]: I just don't understand it.

[Marks]: Okay, so would you be amendable then to updating your conditions to include in the language rather than say that final restoration to other paving in the city, which is the responsibility of National Grid, that the engineering division requested National Grid contribute the cost of final restoration to curbing on Riverside Ave?

[Marks]: OK, so I would ask, Mr. President, that that language be updated.

[Marks]: So we'd read, the engineering division, this is bullet point 12, requests that National Grid contribute the cost of final restoration

[Marks]: to curbing on Riverside Ave.

[Marks]: And then it goes on to say, this can be coordinated with the engineering division, which is perfect.

[Marks]: We have our city engineer that can do that.

[Marks]: So that sounds good.

[Marks]: The second thing, Tim, and you may be able to clarify this, is I'm under the impression that many of our drawings that were lost in the fire down at the old DPW public works building

[Marks]: The drawings were lost that show the corner of Locust Street and Riverside Ave regarding underground utilities.

[Marks]: Is that accurate assessment?

[Marks]: Okay, so at this point, would it make sense to put a condition in there where the road's gonna be ripped up that we look at recreating drawings and digitize our underground utilities at the corner of Locust and Riverside during this construction?

[Marks]: Right, right.

[Marks]: As you said, their pipe is well below yours.

[Marks]: Right.

[Marks]: So it would seem to me that this would be a perfect time, and I defer to the city engineer, that if indeed we don't have these drawings on file, this would be the perfect time to digitize the underground utilities in that area.

[Marks]: Right, right.

[Marks]: But you're doing this job on their behalf.

[Marks]: So now we have leverage through you to the MWRA, right?

[Marks]: So now we're requesting that this take place.

[Marks]: So I could appreciate the fact that you don't have, National Grid doesn't really have any responsibility in that.

[Marks]: But now's the time that we as a community have leverage.

[Marks]: So I would ask the city engineer,

[Marks]: if that would make sense at this point.

[Marks]: OK, so I will leave that up to your expertise.

[Marks]: My last question, and this may be not a question to you, but the Opticom system, I know we have one further down, I believe on Riverside Ave, for fire trucks and ambulances.

[Marks]: Does that wiring happen underground, do you know?

[Marks]: When they wire the intersections?

[Marks]: What's that?

[Marks]: Okay, so maybe Mr. President, if we can ask that question of Head of WIAS.

[Marks]: to ask them, and if the case is that the wiring is underground, this would be an ideal time for the city, rather than dig it up again, because that's a very busy intersection, to run the proper wiring underground while this area is going to be open.

[Marks]: Mr. Randazzo, the head of wires, so we can check to see if the Opti-Com system and the running of wires during this particular project would be worthwhile.

[Marks]: I think that was it, Mr. Clerk.

[Marks]: That's perfect, that the city engineer and the head of wires get together and see if this would be an ideal time to run piping.

[Marks]: Well, if my colleagues feel comfortable, I'm not comfortable with when this project has taken place, but I'm not sure at this point.

[Marks]: Yeah.

[Marks]: Councilor Locks.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I want to thank Council President Falco for bringing this very important issue forward tonight.

[Marks]: I know my council colleagues asked a lot of questions.

[Marks]: I do want to say on the lines of Councilor Bears that if we do indeed leave money on the table, that would be a complete disgrace to leave any money on the table.

[Marks]: Knowing what we know now, Dave, I know you've just been around for a little period of time, but I have a tough time believing over the years that we have not identified through our building grounds and maintenance the need to make updates to exhaust fans, ventilation, HVAC, and so forth.

[Marks]: These issues, issues that have been recognized over the previous years,

[Marks]: Right, so what I'm hearing tonight is that the school district has been aware for many years that they've had some non-instructional reasons that there may be concerns with portions of our buildings, but those particular items have been

[Marks]: kick down, push down the list of priorities for other priorities.

[Marks]: And I think what we're seeing right now and part of the frustration is, and this is no reflection on you in particular, Dave, or the superintendent, or the school committee.

[Marks]: But I think when we look at lack of maintenance within our buildings, and this is not exclusive to the school department because the city side is at fault as well.

[Marks]: We've always kicked the can down the street when it comes to building maintenance and upkeep.

[Marks]: And I think what we're seeing right now is a system that is plagued with a lot of concerns.

[Marks]: And concerns that should have been addressed over the years, now are being addressed because of COVID.

[Marks]: So the one thing that we did get out of COVID was the fact that, in my opinion, these building maintenance concerns, which get brought up every year, and why we don't allocate a certain amount of money to address these needs, because it gets pushed off.

[Marks]: I think this was, if anything, a great learning experience.

[Marks]: And I hope it doesn't become any other experience other than a learning experience at this point.

[Marks]: But the question I have, Dave, is do we anticipate, and this may be a question for Alicia, and I know it's tough to tell, do we anticipate any additional funding, knowing that some of the money's going to dry up at the end of this month, and then we heard at the end of December, do we anticipate any additional funding to address the air quality concerns that are being addressed now?

[Marks]: Right.

[Marks]: And are we able to tap into any of this particular CARES Act money or stimulus money that may be available to address this capital plan that the school committee and the administration is looking at?

[Marks]: Right, no, I understand.

[Marks]: And I understand this is new to everyone, believe me.

[Marks]: This is an emergency that we've never seen the likes of before, so I understand that.

[Marks]: Relating to Council President Falco's question regarding that we knew that COVID-19 was airborne and we knew about this in early March, April.

[Marks]: And I am very concerned why it took so long for the school administration and the school committee to act on moving forward on some of these needs that we have regarding air quality, exhaust fans, and so forth.

[Marks]: And it's pretty troubling to me that we let a fair amount of time go by, and in doing so, potentially a fair amount of money be left on the table, which is very concerning in these troubling times to leave any type of money on the table.

[Marks]: And that really bothers me that there wasn't more of an emphasis on finding out air quality, which is a major concern.

[Marks]: Now to that point,

[Marks]: Have we reached out to the EPA?

[Marks]: Have we exhausted all the rules and regulations and standards from Mass DEP or the Clean Air, Mass Clean Air Act?

[Marks]: And are we required as a school system to look at air quality?

[Marks]: And if so, what, how often are we required to do so?

[Marks]: Yeah, Mr. President, if I could, I asked the question, maybe it's a question for Dave Murphy, but what MAS DP rules or regulations or standards or MAS Clean Air Act or the EPA are we bound by as a school system?

[Marks]: And how often, if any, are we required to do air quality testing?

[Marks]: And if I could, and maybe this is a question for you, Dave, would this money also be available to do improvements such as relating to air quality, such as windows and so forth?

[Marks]: The CARES money in particular.

[Marks]: So just moving forward, Dave, what did we learn about the lack of building maintenance?

[Marks]: Have we learned anything from this?

[Marks]: And just my last point, and I know we talk about school buildings, a lot of people don't envision the vocational school.

[Marks]: But let me tell you, we do have a very well functioning vocational school that's been recognized over the years and there's been a lot of improvements.

[Marks]: And it's very troubling to me, as a former graduate of the vocational school, to hear that we have shops that have poor air quality.

[Marks]: And knowing what takes place in a vocational shop, which is welding, which is automotive, things that emit toxic fumes, knowing that our students are being subjected in these shops to a poor air quality.

[Marks]: really raises a red flag to me.

[Marks]: And I've yet to hear anything really about the vocational school, but it's a major, major concern.

[Marks]: And I think it's something that needs to be addressed immediately.

[Marks]: I know Dave, you mentioned that it's an area that's being looked at, but

[Marks]: With the nature of our shops and the work that's taking place, it's unacceptable to have poor air quality in those particular shops.

[Marks]: And I hope that that's something that's on the radar.

[Marks]: And moving forward, it's something that's reviewed not on an annual basis, but maybe a monthly basis in these shops.

[Marks]: We probably have the same filters in some of those shops when I attended some 40 years ago.

[Marks]: And that's not a joke because of the lack of maintenance and the lack of upkeep.

[Marks]: So I would hope that this special attention paid to our vocational school in those particular shops.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And at the time, three of them were recognized by the city under a previous administration.

[Marks]: One out of the three was initiated on Winthrop Street, Central Ave, and Harvard Street have yet to get their raised crosswalk.

[Marks]: Is that something that's being looked at or can we assume now that it's been several years that that is not being reviewed and no longer is part of the commitment that was made by a previous administration?

[Marks]: Right, and I realize when city administrations change, there may be a different direction in communities.

[Marks]: However, when residents are promised certain items to happen, especially with traffic coming in their neighborhoods, they don't look at it and say, now we have a new mayor, there's a new direction, and we're not going to get the raised crosswalk we were promised under the last mayor.

[Marks]: because now there's a different direction.

[Marks]: I don't think residents see it that way.

[Marks]: They would hope that commitments are kept from administration to administration.

[Marks]: And when you have a pilot program, at some point, a pilot program is supposed to have an end date.

[Marks]: So you're supposed to review how successful the pilot was and either decide to move on with other race crosswalks or decide that they're not useful and don't provide the safety that we need in the community.

[Marks]: But either way, at some point, I think we have to put this issue to rest.

[Marks]: Right, but clearly there's a huge difference, aesthetically speaking, from your initial proposal to this current rendering here.

[Marks]: And I can see why area residents would have some concern with that.

[Marks]: And I don't want to block access or go against their recommendations.

[Marks]: Because right now it just looks like a giant gray, what I would refer to as icebox.

[Marks]: And the exterior of the building looks beautiful, the frontage.

[Marks]: And that, in my opinion, sticks out like a sore thumb.

[Marks]: So I was hoping that maybe the hospital can circle the wagons back and come out with a couple more renderings on other alternatives to just painting that icebox.

[Marks]: that would be aesthetically pleasing for the neighbors and something that I think would fit into the new construction.

[Marks]: So if that's something that the hospital can do, can you speak to that?

[Marks]: Right, so why can't we put some type of screening right onto that mechanical box?

[Marks]: Something that's aesthetically pleasing like the second proposal or maybe some type of building material that could be affixed to the box itself rather than just painting it.

[Marks]: because your initial plan, I'm sure,

[Marks]: was costing tens of thousands of dollars, if not hundreds of thousands of dollars to cover that up.

[Marks]: I'm not sure why we can't take a look at putting something else there that would be pleasing to the neighbors and Director Butters.

[Marks]: So I would ask that that be taken into consideration and that you provide a couple of more proposals other than just the painting of the electrical box itself.

[Marks]: Okay, I'd appreciate it if you can work on that with the CAG group, as well as area residents.

[Marks]: My second question is regarding the exterior of the building, and in particular, the bottom lower part of the building itself.

[Marks]: Do you have any renderings of that?

[Marks]: So the front of the building there,

[Marks]: Well, now the other rendering, the other construction.

[Marks]: Is that a wood slat there, or is that brick?

[Marks]: So is it like a brick master, like a terracotta that's carved in?

[Marks]: Is that what that is?

[Marks]: You said it was a terracotta.

[Marks]: I was wondering if it's similar to like a simulated brick master where they put a layer of cement down and then carve the design that they want to carve into the terracotta or cement, whatever the substance is.

[Marks]: Is the intent to look like brick?

[Marks]: Is that the intent?

[Marks]: OK.

[Marks]: Okay, it doesn't blend in much to me, but if that's what you guys arrived at, that's fine.

[Marks]: My other point I have is regarding, as you know, Ryan, you've been involved with this since day one.

[Marks]: A lot of the direct abutters going up Governor's Ave, there was a lot of discussion in the back of your parking lot, the second lot, regarding fencing, shrubbery, trees.

[Marks]: I know that was part of your presentation.

[Marks]: The home at 216 Governor's Ave has completely no barrier at all from your parking lot.

[Marks]: And I was originally under the impression when we were looking at providing a barrier between the neighbors, whether it was plantings or fencing, that that was part of the project.

[Marks]: Are they not going to put fencing next to 216 Governor's Ave, which would separate your parking lot, a very busy parking lot,

[Marks]: from the residents.

[Marks]: OK.

[Marks]: I would ask respectfully, Lawrence Memorial has been great during this process.

[Marks]: We've come a long way.

[Marks]: And I would ask in the interest of being a good neighbor that I believe it's roughly 100 feet of fence.

[Marks]: that Lawrence Memorial make a commitment to extend that fence so we don't have a neighbor that's completely open to headlights and noise and everything else that's going to be associated with the parking lot.

[Marks]: And I would ask that Lawrence Memorial make a commitment to work with the neighbor at 216 to put up a fence, a barrier, in the interest of being a good neighbor.

[Marks]: Okay, so I take that that sounds like that you will put a fence up.

[Marks]: Okay, I appreciate that.

[Marks]: And just my last point, I know my colleagues have questions also.

[Marks]: During this entire process, some of the concerns within the neighborhood and the direct abutters was speeding cars, additional signage, pedestrian crossings.

[Marks]: And I know much of which involves city input, the traffic commission, the police department.

[Marks]: Has there been any steps with Lawrence Memorial Hospital and the Method Police Department or Traffic Commission to work on some of these concerns regarding speeding and pedestrian safety?

[Marks]: Okay, and do you have anything you could publicly share with us at a later date on what's being proposed and what's being worked on?

[Marks]: Thank you very much.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Mr. President?

[Marks]: I just would like to put my three recommendations in the form of a motion.

[Marks]: The first one would be that two additional renderings of the electrical box

[Marks]: and other alternatives aesthetically pleasing would be provided to the CAG group and to the city council, as well as neighbors and direct abutters, and that a fence be installed between the properties, between the parking lot and 216 Governor's Ave, a full fence, and that as soon as

[Marks]: the discussions had with the police department and the traffic commission regarding public safety, pedestrian safety, and speeding, as well as signage, that those discussions be presented to the council.

[Marks]: I appreciate that.

[Marks]: Marianne, have you had any involvement with the outside rentals of our school buildings?

[Marks]: Okay, so what type of contact tracing is being done by the city or what systems are in place to monitor the size of the groups and the purpose of which they're using our buildings?

[Marks]: Is that being done by your office or is that being done, it is?

[Marks]: Okay.

[Marks]: Is there any actual testing COVID testing being required?

[Marks]: So we don't know if we're welcoming anyone from an outside group into our buildings that may be infected.

[Marks]: Right.

[Marks]: What about a temperature test?

[Marks]: taking someone's temperature.

[Marks]: So as the health director, and I don't mean to put you on the spot, and if you don't want to answer, you don't have to, but what's your personal thought about entertaining activities in a building we're trying to lock down for safety reasons, inviting people from the public into these buildings?

[Marks]: What's your personal thought on that?

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: So Mary, just so I understand, and I don't want to beat a dead horse, but if we had an issue of a student contracting COVID that we know was, or a teacher, or faculty, whoever it might be, that was in the Marsha Karen Little Theater.

[Marks]: And the previous day, there was, or the day after, there was 75 people from an outside organization using the Marsha Karen Theater.

[Marks]: contact every person that we have on record that was in that particular part of the building.

[Marks]: I appreciate that.

[Marks]: So that doesn't make you eligible for contact tracing, although it could make you eligible for getting the COVID virus, correct?

[Marks]: into a building that we're trying to secure for our faculty and our teachers and our students, that we're trying to safeguard and secure, Mr. President.
