[Marks]: And the second motion is the request to the mayor.

[Marks]: No, we still have the second part of this vote.

[Marks]: It is a part two minutes.

[Marks]: Mr. President?

[Marks]: Council Marks?

[Marks]: I disagree with my colleague, Councilor Knight.

[Marks]: I believe that this is an appropriate time.

[Marks]: The paper is currently before the council, and if we want to get it properly vetted through the Community Development Board, which would be a public hearing through the Community Development Board, I think this would be an ideal time, actually, to get this particular language vetted.

[Marks]: And then it has to come back to us, and we can have our legal counsel, Kim Scanlon and KP Law,

[Marks]: take a look at the language to make sure it's appropriate.

[Marks]: I'm under the impression that the city of Boston has a similar language, if not exact language, that mirrors this.

[Marks]: And I believe it spells out a concern that we have for clarification that a brew pub would be listed as a restaurant, and that's based on the sale of 25% or more of its beer on site.

[Marks]: And I think that's a great distinction and something that's needed in our community.

[Marks]: And so I would support moving this forward tonight.

[Marks]: Point of information, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Point of information, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: I thought what was mentioned at the outset that we have to go through this process all over again anyways, because we didn't make the time constraints that were imposed on this council.

[Marks]: So this is nothing more than adding a definition to the current brewing ordinance that we have that's going to probably be vetted once again.

[Marks]: And if anything, Mr. President, this is merely stating that

[Marks]: Food will be 75% of what's sold in the establishment, which would make it a restaurant.

[Marks]: And only 25% can be of a brewing nature.

[Marks]: So it's actually very different than the other definitions, where it heavily relies on the brewing and not the food.

[Marks]: And so this is more food-related than it is brewing.

[Marks]: And I think it fits well into this, because it gives people an option, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I think it will probably be vetted out as we go along.

[Marks]: So I will support it tonight.

[Marks]: knowing that we still have many meetings in front of us, Mr. President, to go forward with this.

[Marks]: Mr. President, just if I could add, we were fortunate enough, and I appreciate all the work Council and I did on this, believe me, and other members of the council, we put a lot of time and effort into this, as well as Mark Rumley, former city solicitor, who actually got this ball rolling as well, Mr. President.

[Marks]: But we were fortunate enough to have a couple of Method residents,

[Marks]: that are in the brewing business to assist us and help us along in crafting this ordinance to make it work for the city of Medford.

[Marks]: So I only see that as a positive that we had the ability to have someone there give us some guidance and there was many times that we asked for guidance to make sure we crafted something that wasn't a Somerville ordinance or Cambridge or Boston but a Method ordinance to see how it worked for us.

[Marks]: And so

[Marks]: I continue to look for advice and assistance and any other assistance I can get from the people that have the expertise.

[Marks]: Because I'm not a brewing expert, I don't know the number of barrels, I don't know anything that...

[Marks]: what I have to do my homework and research.

[Marks]: And from what I see with this, Mr. President, it will be properly vetted.

[Marks]: We're not asking that this be voted on tonight and then become an ordinance, ordained ordinance, in the next several weeks.

[Marks]: We're saying that this has to go through the entire process again.

[Marks]: Unfortunately, we have to do it.

[Marks]: We have to go through the entire process and have another public hearing and so forth.

[Marks]: Even though much of the language has been vetted out,

[Marks]: So I hear what Councilor Knight's saying, but I think we should at least give this the opportunity to be added and then properly vetted.

[Marks]: the National Grid one?

[Marks]: You are correct.

[Marks]: And I realize under state statute, it only allows us to use that money for certain purposes, and one being to offset a budget deficit.

[Marks]: And in the past, I've been on the council for a number of years, we have dipped into that money to use to offset our snow and ice account in the city budget.

[Marks]: Between the year of 2017 and 2020, there were 139 accidents reported at the area of Main and Salt Street.

[Marks]: Mr. President, I think as I stated, I think it was last week, we have more in common than we do when it comes to what we believe needs to be done in regards to police reform.

[Marks]: I've had the opportunity over the last two weeks, actually, maybe even longer, to speak with some of the police officers.

[Marks]: And a few things that they mentioned to me, I think most people may even find a little surprising.

[Marks]: I think there's a lot of support among police officers regarding civilian review boards, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And with the one caveat that if you do set up a board that it be

[Marks]: manned with people that have a working knowledge of how a police department operates, the role of a police department.

[Marks]: So they are open to that, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The union, according to Harold McGillivray, has met with the administration and wants to implement cameras.

[Marks]: for not only the safety of the general public, but for the safety of the officers.

[Marks]: So that's another thing, Mr. President, I think that if we start talking reform, that I think we have more in common, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The last point I'd like to make, and I said this last week, and I think there's a lot of support for it.

[Marks]: We rely on our police department for almost everything.

[Marks]: You know, they're the only department open seven days a week, 24 hours a day.

[Marks]: So when something happens in the community, Mr. President, you know, and it's after five o'clock, we just don't say, well, you know what, we'll handle it tomorrow.

[Marks]: It's the police department that responds.

[Marks]: And we're asking the men and women of our police department, Mr. President, to respond to issues of domestic violence.

[Marks]: We're asking them to respond to drug issues and people that are ODing.

[Marks]: We're asking them to respond to mental health issues.

[Marks]: We're asking them to respond to social issues, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And in my opinion, we're asking them to do a lot in addition to what their main responsibility is, is to keep public order and to prevent crimes and to protect the life and liberty of property.

[Marks]: They have a lot on their plate, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And from what I'm hearing from people when they talk about cutting the police department or defunding the police department, I think it has very many meanings.

[Marks]: And from what I'm hearing from a lot of people is they don't necessarily want to cut the police.

[Marks]: They want to give the assistance they believe the police officers should have.

[Marks]: So if there's a call, Mr. President, regarding domestic violence,

[Marks]: Why not have someone that's a domestic violence specialist, Mr. President, on hand that can go to calls, Mr. President, that can attend calls, that can assist?

[Marks]: Why not have someone that's a social worker that can attend calls, Mr. President, that may require that?

[Marks]: Or someone that has a mental health background

[Marks]: if the issue requires mental health, Mr. President.

[Marks]: There's a lot of ways we can assist the police department, Mr. President, and provide the safety, which I agree.

[Marks]: You know, we may have issues that are happening in the community that require other expertise.

[Marks]: And why not have the availability, Mr. President, and the availability to de-escalate situations?

[Marks]: And so I think there's a lot more in common than we realize

[Marks]: I think there would be a lot more support out there, Mr. President, once these discussions are had.

[Marks]: And I think we're going to move towards police reform that's going to be acceptable to everyone, Mr. President.

[Marks]: It'll be a win-win.

[Marks]: And I think that will not only improve communications within our community, but it'll also assist the brave men and women in our police department, Mr. President, to do their very taxing job.

[Marks]: And, you know, I think we all want to arrive at the same results, Mr. President, and that is to provide a safe community.

[Marks]: That's the number one job of the Medford City Council, is to provide a safe community, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And without public safety, we have nothing else in the community.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Marks]: Mr. President, I didn't have a chance to review.

[Marks]: I would ask that they lay on the table.

[Marks]: Topic is not something we cannot run from.

[Marks]: It's something we need to address and embrace.

[Marks]: And you have our commitment to do so.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I think if we all recall, this may have gave us a commitment that we were going to get the budget in April.

[Marks]: That would have been the earliest budget, Mr. President, I've been on 20 years on the council, that this council has ever received a budget.

[Marks]: And then we had what we all know COVID-19 came into effect, Mr. President, and threw a monkey wrench into that.

[Marks]: So the commitment was out there, Mr. President, to get us an early budget.

[Marks]: And we're faced now with a $10 million deficit.

[Marks]: And although some would like to see a budget immediately, I think it's only prudent that the mayor take the time, Mr. President, to wait to see the local aid, what we're going to receive, to see what local receipts may be coming in.

[Marks]: We also waited, Mr. President, which we all know, because they extended the period to pay your taxes.

[Marks]: So we wanted to see what revenue we had in order to put together a budget.

[Marks]: So I appreciate the fact that my colleagues have concern, but I can tell you from experience, Mr. President, I remember getting the budget with one night to work on it.

[Marks]: And I remember, Mr. President, in the past, there wasn't much outcry for many years, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And now all of a sudden, in the middle of COVID-19, there's an outcry to get the budget, which we never got this early, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So it's great people want to see the budget.

[Marks]: I'm eager to see the budget.

[Marks]: We need to move forward, Mr. President.

[Marks]: But by no stretch of the imagination is this city administration holding

[Marks]: anything back.

[Marks]: They're trying to put together a budget that will provide city services, that will keep people employed, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The last thing we want to do is send out a budget to alarm people that they may be losing their job, and then we get a federal stimulus.

[Marks]: or we get a bailout.

[Marks]: And guess what?

[Marks]: When you were worried about your job for the last three weeks, you don't have to worry.

[Marks]: The last thing we do is want to worry people, Mr. President.

[Marks]: We're all going to have ample time to meet with the department heads.

[Marks]: We're going to have ample time to go over the budget, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And we're going to have ample time to make sure we have input.

[Marks]: So don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

[Marks]: The process has worked this way, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I feel comfortable that we're moving forward with a realistic budget.

[Marks]: I don't want to see a budget that's not realistic, because I've dealt with one for the last 20 years.

[Marks]: I want to see a realistic budget.

[Marks]: And I think that's what this current administration is working on, Mr. President, in a time of emergency, in a time of a pandemic, and a lot more happening, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Mr. President, that was a preliminary budget that every mayor for the last 30 years works on, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And if someone wants to create the budget, maybe they should run for mayor.

[Marks]: Because it's the mayor's responsibility to create the budget and then pass it on to the council, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I don't know why we're putting the cop before the horse, Mr. President.

[Marks]: It's never happened in previous years, and there was never anyone outspoken in previous years.

[Marks]: But now, I guess in COVID-19, we have different expectations, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And you can imagine people paying bills for consumption that they didn't use.

[Marks]: So it was a nightmare.

[Marks]: It's just to have them.

[Marks]: So if a meter does start to malfunction, you're going to have the ability to replace the head or replace the entire meter.

[Marks]: So, uh, Mr. President, if I could, uh, just, um, uh, amend this if I could, or, uh, have a request to the city administration that we get an update on, uh, the, uh, re-metering.

[Marks]: We're 15 years into a life expectancy of roughly 10 to 11 years.

[Marks]: I have to put in a plug for catch basins.

[Marks]: They're not capturing this water and cutting it out to the Mystic River.

[Marks]: So I would offer those two suggestions that the administration report back on a meter replacement plan, and also what the plan is for repairing or replacing our catch basins that currently exist are ones that are broken and caving in throughout the community.

[Marks]: This is great news.

[Marks]: Finally, I think we see some positive results from many thousands of complaints filed by Medford residents regarding airplane noise that started back in 2013.

[Marks]: when Massport implemented a flight patent that unfairly and disproportionately pushed and exposed Method residents to noise from runway 33L.

[Marks]: And that's been a bone of contention, not just with the city of Medford, but many surrounding communities.

[Marks]: There was efforts to join with surrounding communities, of which we joined with Arlington, Somerville, Belmont, Watertown, requesting the FAA study, the changes that were identified in the MIT study that was commissioned.

[Marks]: I want to thank Councilor Caraviello for bringing this up.

[Marks]: He brings a lot of valid points up regarding much-needed affordable housing, which I think we all can agree upon, additional revenue from building permits and so forth, which I think we all agree upon.

[Marks]: I think the one issue, Mr. President, we do have to look at is that the fact that this law has been around for five decades.

[Marks]: And if you look at the statistics, 80% of the communities in Massachusetts fall below the 10% threshold.

[Marks]: So even though this law has been out there for five decades, it's done very little to add affordable housing.

[Marks]: And I agree with my colleagues, I agree with Councilor Knight said, I think a friendly 40B is something we should be looking at as a community.

[Marks]: I also think there are housing production plans that, within the last two years, 150 cities and towns have taken advantage of, which is a way of creating a blueprint in a community that allows you to move forward on these larger projects that have affordability components.

[Marks]: And those are less contentious.

[Marks]: They're good ways of moving forward with developers and suiting the needs of a community, but also not rolling over either, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Because, you know, if we talk about fairness, let's face it, these particular projects, a thousand units are within a square mile of each other.

[Marks]: They're not spread around the community, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I could just tell you, Mr. President, in my neighborhood alone, they've added hundreds, if not thousands of units in the last year and a half in one neighborhood, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I think when we have to take a look at this, and maybe when we start looking at zoning, this will be an issue we do take a look at, Mr. President.

[Marks]: But we have to make sure that if we're going to create these projects, especially these larger projects, that they're created fairly and evenly distributed around the community, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I think that's vital.

[Marks]: And those are things that I think we have to look at.

[Marks]: So I don't fault the administration for standing up on behalf of the community and saying, these are mitigating factors we're going to be looking for.

[Marks]: These are things that we want to safeguard neighborhoods.

[Marks]: These are issues that we're concerned about.

[Marks]: I don't fault them for that.

[Marks]: But I would like to see a collaborative effort when the developers do come in so we can work on this and not waste money with attorneys.

[Marks]: Because the only one that gains are the attorneys making money.

[Marks]: And so I'd like to see a collaborative effort.

[Marks]: when this happens, and I'd like to see a little more thought, Mr. President, to make sure that these projects are equally dispersed.

[Marks]: Why should one neighborhood experience thousands of more traffic trips and thousands of more cars on the street while other neighborhoods don't see anything at all, Mr. President?

[Marks]: So, you know, if we're going to stand up and talk about fairness, we have to have the discussion, although it may be painful because people don't want to talk about it, Mr. President, but it's something that we need to discuss as a council.

[Marks]: And I thank my colleagues for bringing this up.

[Marks]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Councilor Peers.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I want to thank my colleagues for bringing this up.

[Marks]: And once that's lifted, this would no longer apply.

[Marks]: And secondly, Mr. President, what actually troubles me more

[Marks]: than the exorbitant fees that they're charging, to be quite honest with you, is the fact that many of these small business owners have opted to offer discounts if you call them directly.

[Marks]: And because Grubhub and DoorDash and Uber Eats has such a market power, that they're able to prevent the restaurants from offering their own incentive for people to call them directly.

[Marks]: and at a discount.

[Marks]: So they really have cornered the market, Mr. President, especially now with COVID and the need for delivery and so forth.

[Marks]: And I think anything we can do to help the small business at least get through this timeframe, I think is warranted.

[Marks]: So I will support this tonight, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Councilor Bears.

[Marks]: No, Mr. President, if I could.

[Marks]: Oh, yes.

[Marks]: really complex and a lot of moving parts.

[Marks]: And I think we came out with a document that fits this city.

[Marks]: This is unique to the city of Medford and how it applies.

[Marks]: And I think it works well within our community.

[Marks]: It allows establishments to come in.

[Marks]: voted a majority to allow marijuana shops within the city of Medford.

[Marks]: Maybe you want to let the general public know that.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I do want to echo the sentiments of my colleagues.

[Marks]: You know, it's almost like the Wizard of Oz that, you know, the department is severely understaffed and there are very few people behind the curtain.

[Marks]: But let me tell you, they get the job done on a daily basis.

[Marks]: And from the leader, Brian Cairns on down, they do a tremendous work on behalf of the residents of this community.

[Marks]: We're very attentive in addressing issues and as Councilor Caraviello mentioned, you know, they're out there in the cold nights and the hot days doing what it takes to keep our city moving forward.

[Marks]: And I just want to thank them all personally.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I want to thank Vice President Caraviello for putting this on.

[Marks]: 90 years young, May Makibrek, what an accomplishment.

[Marks]: You know, I had the unique opportunity to serve on the Methodist Council, incorporated with May on the board.

[Marks]: Talking about someone that's a plugger, a go-getter, never took no for an answer, and truly was unselfish when it came to never wanting the recognition, just wanting to get things done in the community.

[Marks]: If it wasn't for May, you could safely say the Boys and Girls Club would not exist.

[Marks]: If it wasn't for May, the Friends of Chevalier wouldn't be supporting the Chevalier Auditorium for the many, many years and all the improvements that were done to Chevalier.

[Marks]: You know, May has been instrumental in this community and continues to be instrumental in this community.

[Marks]: And I just want to personally

[Marks]: congratulator and wish her another hundred years of community involvement in this community, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I rise once again with my fellow colleagues to bring up the concern of public safety, in particular at the corner of Main Street and South Street and along the entirety of South Street.

[Marks]: Last we spoke, Mr. President, I think it was a couple of months ago, we brought up this issue regarding some of the traffic calming initiatives that were pushed forward during a public meeting that hundreds of residents in the area attended, and of which many of the initiatives that were sent to the Traffic Commission have yet to be done, Mr. President, which is a little alarming.

[Marks]: Also, Mr. President, within the last couple of months, and I have talked to Chief Buckley just recently, and I'm in the process of getting the traffic accidents in that particular area from the chief, an update.

[Marks]: There has been several major traffic accidents on that particular corner in the last couple of months.

[Marks]: So this is an issue that's not going away.

[Marks]: It's existed for, I'd have to say since I've been on the council,

[Marks]: So 20 years, Mr. President, we've been asking for some relief.

[Marks]: As we all know, that section of the corner of Main and South is a state road, and they have jurisdiction over that particular piece of road that we are discussing.

[Marks]: So what I did, Mr. President, I went through some of the studies that were initiated by this community since 2005.

[Marks]: And I found it pretty interesting that each study that I looked at all spoke about the need for traffic calming and traffic improvements, safety improvements in the Method Square area.

[Marks]: So this has been since 2005, over four reports that I could get my hands on, and I'm sure there were more, Mr. President, all spoke about initiatives that should be done in our community to improve traffic flow, pedestrian,

[Marks]: bicycles, and in my opinion, very little has been acted upon.

[Marks]: So the most recent report we have was December 2018, which was the Method Square Priority Roadway Improvement Study.

[Marks]: And that was done by the Boston Regional Metropolitan Planning Organization.

[Marks]: And that was commissioned in December, 2018.

[Marks]: Uh, they came out with, uh, I don't know if it was a 40, 50 page report, uh, that talked about, uh, the method square surrounding area and ways to make improvements of which, um, I'd like to go through Mr. President, their recommendations.

[Marks]: for the Medford Square area, and I'd like to isolate not on all their recommendations, but the intersection of South Street and Main Street, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I will get into that.

[Marks]: The second report that was commissioned by the city was December 2017.

[Marks]: So it was a year before the Medford Square Priority Roadway Improvement Plan.

[Marks]: And that was the Medford Square Master Plan.

[Marks]: And that was done by the Metro Area Planning Council.

[Marks]: And that had an associated cost of $90,000.

[Marks]: That also got into the improvements and traffic calming improvements that were needed in the Medford Square area.

[Marks]: I am not going to get into that, Mr. President, because I think much of that is covered in the Medford Square priority roadway improvement.

[Marks]: The report prior to that was in the fall of 2006.

[Marks]: It was the Medford Square and Mystic River Reconnection, Revitalization, and Redevelopment Study.

[Marks]: And that was done by MIT.

[Marks]: And that talked about parking.

[Marks]: It talked about improvements to the downtown area.

[Marks]: It talked about revitalizing business.

[Marks]: That encompassed a lot more than just roadways.

[Marks]: However, the roadway in question, Salt Street and Main,

[Marks]: was mentioned, Mr. President, and ways to improve that.

[Marks]: That was back in 2006.

[Marks]: And the last report I could find was the original Medford Square Master Plan, which was done by Sasaki in June of 2005.

[Marks]: And that had an associated cost of a little over $100,000.

[Marks]: And I don't have the cost of the other studies.

[Marks]: So the two that I have, Mr. President, were close to $200,000 in studies with very little in the way of improvements to our roadways, which

[Marks]: To me, Mr. President, is alarming when we have to talk about it year after year and know that as time goes by, accidents increase, pedestrian safety is at an all time dangerous rate in that particular area.

[Marks]: And that should concern all of us.

[Marks]: So December 2018, the Metropolitan Planning Organization conducted this study.

[Marks]: As I mentioned, the study is part of the MPO series of ongoing studies that addresses safety, mobility, and access of the Boston region's priority roadways.

[Marks]: This report identifies specific issues and concerns in Medford Square study area, presents an in-depth analysis of multiple transportation-related factors, and recommends potential short, long-term solutions to problems, including improvement alternatives.

[Marks]: So the study goes on to talk about 2.4 total miles of needed improvements on our roadways at many different sections.

[Marks]: I'm just going to focus, Mr. President, on the Main Street, Route 38 from Salem Street to Mystic Ave.

[Marks]: And that calls into question, as we all know, the South Street and Main Street connection.

[Marks]: So Mr. President, in 2000, 2013, and 2015, mass DOT data shows that the crash clusters

[Marks]: that are present throughout the entire study area, which I just alluded to this five different major study areas.

[Marks]: They were ranked in the top 5% of crash locations in the Boston region MPO area.

[Marks]: So we have five locations in Medford that are in the top 5% of crash clusters.

[Marks]: That speaks volumes, Mr. President, and that was indicated within this December 2018 report.

[Marks]: It goes on to say, Mr. President, that the Main Street corridor from Craddock Bridge to Mystic Ave, whose two most concerning intersections are Main Street at Route 16 ramps and Main Street at Mystic Ave, which is the area that we're focusing on, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The issues of concern

[Marks]: I know we're all, some of us, this is old hat.

[Marks]: But I think we've got to keep on revisiting this, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I had a talk today with Christine Barber, our state representative, who assured me that there's transportation bond bill money that is for the purpose of putting signalization throughout the square, which was a major recommendation.

[Marks]: I think there was an estimated cost, which I brought up several months back at, I want to say, $4 to $5 million,

[Marks]: which sounds like overkill in my opinion, but that's what they came out with.

[Marks]: But according to Representative Barber, that there is money in the transportation bond bill.

[Marks]: It just has to be freed up.

[Marks]: So, issues of concern, there is considerable traffic on Main Street during the a.m.

[Marks]: and p.m.

[Marks]: peak periods.

[Marks]: Anyone crossing those streets realize, as Councilor Scarpelli mentioned, it's a game of chicken or frog.

[Marks]: Frogger trying to cross those streets and even just trying to get out onto Main Street is you're taking your life in your hands.

[Marks]: The intersection at Main Street Route 16 ramps is currently un-signalized with stop controls at Route 16 westbound off-ramp and South Street joined by Route 16 eastbound off-ramp.

[Marks]: During peak traffic periods, the stop control approaches are extremely congested.

[Marks]: The intersection of Main Street and Mystic Ave currently operates with flashing yellow on Main Street southbound and Mystic Ave flashing red on Main Street northbound during peak periods.

[Marks]: Vehicles on Main Street northbound endure extensive delays and frequently force themselves into the intersection, what causes potential conflicts with prevailing traffic and sometimes gridlock.

[Marks]: the intersection.

[Marks]: These two intersections have a crash rate much higher than the district floor average of un-signalized sections.

[Marks]: So it's ranked in the top 5% and it has a much higher average of crashes than other un-signalized intersections.

[Marks]: With no traffic signals, with pedestrian phases, and under heavy traffic, pedestrians usually have a difficult time crossing the two intersections.

[Marks]: Pedestrian crosswalk markings on Main Street are faded.

[Marks]: That was 2018.

[Marks]: They have since painted the crosswalks.

[Marks]: There are no sufficient shoulders or clearly marked shared road bicycle accommodations on Main Street and Mystic Ave.

[Marks]: So the report went on, Mr. President, and the reason why I bring this up is we don't have to recreate the wheel when it comes to what needs to be done.

[Marks]: We have four commission reports by organizations that came in, did a thorough investigation, had community input, public hearings, and made recommendations.

[Marks]: And here we are 15 years later, and we're no closer to addressing our concerns.

[Marks]: But yet, accidents continue to happen.

[Marks]: Very serious accidents, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So the proposed short-term improvements, and I'll go over them briefly, regularly maintain the crosswalks.

[Marks]: You would think that would be a no-brainer, but in our community, it's something that has to be revisited every year.

[Marks]: You know, I asked for thermal plastic crosswalks, which don't need repainting every year.

[Marks]: They last five years, they're slip resistant, they're highly reflective, and we still don't incorporate that as a common practice in our community.

[Marks]: which it's a little more expensive, but the state uses them and every other large agency and city uses thermoplastic in the use of their pavement markings.

[Marks]: Install stripe yield lines in both directions at the crosswalk on Main Street near the police station.

[Marks]: Consider removing on-street parking in front of the police station and providing at least five foot shoulders on both sides

[Marks]: of Main Street.

[Marks]: Install striped sharrows at appropriate locations of both streets south of the intersection of Main Street and Mystic Ave.

[Marks]: Support development on South Method Connector, a multi-use path on South Bank of the Mystic River that would connect the Mystic Greenway currently understudied by the City of Method and the Mystic River Watershed Association.

[Marks]: long-term improvements.

[Marks]: Both the intersection of Main Street at Route 16 ramps and Main Street at Mystic Ave should be signalized and reconstructed.

[Marks]: Main Street at Route 16, in summary, this study proposes alternative 1A and 1B for the interchange, long-term improvements.

[Marks]: 1A, signalize the two ramp intersections under one controller with three phase traffic operations and concurrent pedestrian phases.

[Marks]: Now, Mr. President, I need to add that this does not talk about signalization all the way from Salem Street, which we were originally told by the state would run us anywhere from $3 to $5 million.

[Marks]: This is far more of a centralized approach to alleviate the concerns we have on the Main Street, South Street area to Mystic Ave.

[Marks]: Alternative B, signalize the two ramp intersections under one controller with four-phase traffic operations and concurrent pedestrian phases.

[Marks]: So, Mr. President, I won't get into all the other improvements, but I do have them and I am going to list them, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I would ask that as part of this report, the funding that MassDOT says is clearly available for this project.

[Marks]: And I would ask any of my colleagues to go on to the FY, the 2018 Medford Square Priority Roadway Improvement Study.

[Marks]: And they could see that for themselves that the state is saying funding is available for this particular project.

[Marks]: So I don't know why we're in a quandary now, how we're going to pay for this and why we haven't moved forward on this project for at least the last two years since we received this report, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I would ask that through our traffic engineer and through our engineer that we find out about the funding.

[Marks]: that DOT admits is available to the city of Medford for the Route 16, Mystic Ave portion of improvements that were mentioned within the Priority Roadway Improvement Study of 2018.

[Marks]: I would also ask, Mr. President, once again, I think we did this six months ago, and I don't recall a response.

[Marks]: Maybe my colleagues can correct me.

[Marks]: but the council recommended during a public meeting with hundreds of residents from the South Street area, some simple low-lying fruit of stop signs, widening sidewalks, raised crosswalks, maybe even a pedestrian crossing light on South Street in general.

[Marks]: And there may have been one or two improvements, but largely, Mr. President, many of the recommendations that were forwarded to the traffic commission have not been acted upon yet.

[Marks]: So I think anyone that's been on the Council for a number of years can recall the Locust Street project and how members of the Council, when we sat down with the developer,

[Marks]: were urging, and I believe Council Vice President Caraviello did the same, we were urging them to add more retail space within the project itself.

[Marks]: They were strictly looking to put residential.

[Marks]: And we didn't wanna create these giant housing outlets that had no community feel to them.

[Marks]: And so I think this is one way of attaching whatever's built.

[Marks]: And I don't think this applies to small mom and pop, two or three family homes and so forth.

[Marks]: This is large scale projects that they have some type of community feel to it.

[Marks]: that, you know, for instance, when we looked at the revitalization of Medford Square, the projects that were sent to us had very little commercial retail space within them.

[Marks]: It was all residential.

[Marks]: So on the east side of Medford Square near City Hall, it kind of created just an area where there was housing and no reason to go, to be quite honest with you.

[Marks]: And that was something that we were looking at as a council saying, you know what, we don't want these large scale projects taking place without that community feeling and without that community input.

[Marks]: So I welcome this for anyone to think that because we started this process of recodifying that we shouldn't look at anything else for the next year should have their head examined.

[Marks]: Because we should always be looking for low-lying fruit.

[Marks]: We should always be looking to take advantage of ways that we may be able to push something forward, Mr. President, and not wait if it's something we can do easily, Mr. President.

[Marks]: To me, this is something worth exploring.

[Marks]: I think it merits, I will support sending it to the community development.

[Marks]: So to say that there's no public hearings or public input won't take place is not correct, Mr. President.

[Marks]: There will be ample time for public input, public hearings, business input, and that's the process that we follow.

[Marks]: So I support this, Mr. President.

[Marks]: you know, any way we can improve the process in our community.

[Marks]: And I think this is one way of keeping our commercial base up.

[Marks]: which we know once that dwindles, residential taxpayers are going to feel the burden.

[Marks]: We have the city engineer here to present regarding safe routes to school project.

[Marks]: And first, I'd like to applaud the Brooks School for, I believe it's been six years for this grant.

[Marks]: Tim, I had a question for you.

[Marks]: We talked about easements.

[Marks]: Also, there are several properties that are privately owned that have private property on city property.

[Marks]: And I was told by yourself that the state was going to put out an agreement that they weren't going to go after property owners that may have encroached on city property.

[Marks]: Could you just give us a little update on that?

[Marks]: Okay, so just so I understand then regarding this current project of St.

[Marks]: Ruth's to school, there will be no property, city resident property that will be taken.

[Marks]: Um, and Mr. President, if I could, I know there, uh, were a number of concerns by, uh, residents, area residents on high street and some of the, uh, budding streets.

[Marks]: Um, the traffic commission, uh, had a meeting, uh, several months back regarding, uh, the taking of parking spots along high street.

[Marks]: Uh, so this project can move forward.

[Marks]: I know many residents voiced their concern, um, naturally.

[Marks]: Parking is at a premium, and let's face it, no one wants to lose a parking spot.

[Marks]: And we as a council voted unanimously, I believe it was several months back, to ask if DOT and the city could get together and see if they can explore some other options where we may be able to save some parking along High Street.

[Marks]: And apparently that didn't bear any fruit, those discussions.

[Marks]: However, Mr. President, at the traffic commission meeting, there were several residents that brought up to the traffic commission whether or not they could take a bike lane.

[Marks]: And during non-peak time, for instance, 7 p.m.

[Marks]: or 8 p.m.

[Marks]: at night, have it revert to parking, area parking from 7 p.m., 8 p.m.

[Marks]: at night to 6 a.m.

[Marks]: or 7 a.m.

[Marks]: in the morning.

[Marks]: And the traffic commission said they were going to look into it.

[Marks]: I had a discussion today with Chief Buckley, and he reiterated his concerns that, first of all, that DOT made it clear that this project had to have a bike lane.

[Marks]: And none of us want to jeopardize a million dollars.

[Marks]: However, I did ask him if the traffic commission was going to explore

[Marks]: possibly turning this bike lane for non-peak hours into parking spots.

[Marks]: And he said they are going to explore that.

[Marks]: So I did get a reassurance from Chief Buckley today that that was under advisement.

[Marks]: The second piece I just want to touch upon, as Councilor Caraviello mentioned, I received a number of emails from people today in support of the project.

[Marks]: And like I said, 99% of this project I do support.

[Marks]: The one concern I have, Mr. President, which I found a little terrifying in several of the emails I received, is residents saying that they now can have their elementary school child use High Street to bike to school.

[Marks]: That really concerns me, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I'm not one to put a rubber stamp on anything.

[Marks]: And the fact that we may be able to get money for this project is great.

[Marks]: And the fact that this project has a big public safety component in it is great.

[Marks]: And the traffic calming component is great.

[Marks]: The one concern I do have, Mr. President, and I know the city engineer said we have more plans to extend our bike lanes.

[Marks]: The reason why we were told at the beginning the bike lane was going to be on that side of High Street was

[Marks]: that it's the safest side because when you have bicyclists traveling, for what we were told, you want them, because they're going at a slower speed, to travel uphill rather than downhill.

[Marks]: And that made it for a safer area and that's why they decided

[Marks]: to make the bike lane go up High Street rather than down High Street.

[Marks]: That was my understanding.

[Marks]: My concern is, Mr. President, if residents feel comfortable now having their child bike to school, especially elementary kids on a very, very busy road on High Street, we have a four-block bike lane that goes up High Street, which is the slow part when you're riding a bike, and all of a sudden it stops at the top by Hastings Lane.

[Marks]: And it goes into the downward slope down High Street and a very winding, dangerous part of High Street, extremely dangerous.

[Marks]: And I think we'd all be negligent if we didn't step up and say, you know what?

[Marks]: If we're going to do the bike lane, for the very least, we should extend this, whether it's part of this project or part of the city project, whatever it might be.

[Marks]: I, in good conscience, have a tough time saying, OK, we'll accept the money, we'll put the bike lane for four blocks, and no one will be the wiser.

[Marks]: Because I foresee a problem, Mr. President,

[Marks]: especially if residents think now we're creating a safe zone for children to ride their bikes.

[Marks]: That is not a safe zone.

[Marks]: And the way it breaks off, Mr. President, if anyone's familiar, at the top of Hastings, then it winds down.

[Marks]: That is a very dangerous area to all of a sudden have a bike lane stop, especially for young kids.

[Marks]: So I'd like, Mr. President, to offer a motion tonight that we as a city, if we're going to move forward with this project,

[Marks]: And I'll leave it up to the city engineer.

[Marks]: I'll leave it up to the traffic engineer to decide when to get to Winthrop Circle and so forth and let them decide the logistics of it.

[Marks]: But I can't have in my conscience to leave a bike path just because it's getting funded for four blocks.

[Marks]: We should turn a blind eye as a city and say, well, that's fine with us.

[Marks]: That's great.

[Marks]: We're not going to turn down the money.

[Marks]: We should step up, Mr. President, to the plate.

[Marks]: And if you're talking about spots, there's no loss of parking spots on that point of High Street that winds down.

[Marks]: That would be an ideal place to continue the bike lane.

[Marks]: And then when we tell parents, we're creating safe routes to school, we're really creating a safe route.

[Marks]: Because four blocks that leads to an area that's a dangerous area is not a safe route, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And so I'm going to offer that tonight as a motion that, you know, I'm going to support this project, but it has to be, Mr. President, that we have our city engineer and we'll ask the mayor, because the mayor presented this paper to us, to give us a commitment that that bike lane will be extended, Mr. President, not in the future, but now as part of this project.

[Marks]: And if the city has to pick up the cost, then so be it, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Mr. President, the reason why I say that, I'm not a traffic engineer.

[Marks]: I'm not a parking engineer.

[Marks]: And I don't have to be an engineer to make that decision.

[Marks]: And it was just really recent, of recent time,

[Marks]: that the Zoning Board of Appeals started to flex their muscle and issue use variances.

[Marks]: In 2016, Mr. President, the Method City Council sued our own Zoning Board of Appeals.

[Marks]: And one part of the suit was that the voting board gave out too many variances, and also that use variances are not authorized in the city of Medford.

[Marks]: That came from a unanimous vote of the Medford City Council.

[Marks]: after we hired a zoning attorney to represent us.

[Marks]: So as early as 2016, June of 2016, we were on record as a council saying, it's illegal what the zoning board did by giving the use variance.

[Marks]: two houses down from you, take it from a residential zone to a commercial zone or industrial zone, give them that authority.

[Marks]: Yeah, I do.

[Marks]: Don't tell them about the gap.

[Marks]: I heard everything, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Where was I?

[Marks]: Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: This may sound familiar to some of my colleagues.

[Marks]: Several months back, I offered a very similar resolution.

[Marks]: The reason why I bring it up again this evening is the fact that last week when we were discussing the budget, it was mentioned that we could look and potentially save some money with the waste management contract.

[Marks]: which we all, I should say we all, which I thought was coming up at the end of this year for renewal.

[Marks]: And come to find out when the mayor mentioned it doesn't renew until 2023, Dave Rodriguez, the chief of staff, sent us a copy of the amended contract.

[Marks]: I was on the council at the time, Mr. President, and I looked through my records.

[Marks]: I can't find anywhere that the city administration entered into a new renewal with waste management.

[Marks]: Now, I know it happened, so I'm not trying to say it didn't happen.

[Marks]: But at the time, back in 2010, the city administration, and I just want to give a little

[Marks]: history on this.

[Marks]: The city administration, Mr. President signed a nine year eight or nine month contract.

[Marks]: So it's 9.75 year contract with waste management.

[Marks]: Now, in order to enter that contract by state law, anything over three years has to be approved by the council, any contract with a length over three years.

[Marks]: So then Mayor McGlynn approached the council and asked that we approve a 10-year contract, which we did, Mr. President, at the time, because there was some savings in the contract.

[Marks]: Unbeknownst to me, some three and a half years later, into a 10-year contract, the mayor went back and extended the contract another three years, which he was able to do so under state statute.

[Marks]: So it went from a 10-year contract, almost a 10-year contract, to a 13-year contract, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I found it ironic that at the time when the mayor renegotiated, waste management gave us an incentive of $400,000 to renegotiate the contract.

[Marks]: And the only other change, Mr. President, was an increase in the recyclable rates.

[Marks]: So there's a fee that they're processing fee that went up from $50 per ton to $85 per ton.

[Marks]: which would lead someone to believe, why would you be negotiating after you have a 10-year contract for a higher rate for recycling?

[Marks]: It doesn't make any sense.

[Marks]: Unless, of course, you're looking for a quick fix of some incentive money, which the city received.

[Marks]: Putting that all aside, Mr. President, because I'm going to bring that up another time.

[Marks]: I offered a resolution on behalf of Maple Park condominiums because currently right now they only have recycling.

[Marks]: So when the contract was made, apparently the city went around back some years ago to all the condominium associations and said, how would you like to participate?

[Marks]: Would you like bulk pickup?

[Marks]: Would you like recycling?

[Marks]: Would you like trash pickup?

[Marks]: And at the time, the different condo associations chose what they wanted.

[Marks]: Some opted, like Maple Condominiums, Park Condominiums, opted just for recycling only.

[Marks]: Now, several years later, they said, you know what?

[Marks]: We'd like to get into the bulk pickup.

[Marks]: We'd be interested in that.

[Marks]: And other condos have approached the administration previous administrations and they were allowed into different aspects of the program And they are asking now to be part of bulk pickup.

[Marks]: So i'm requesting originally the council if you remember we voted to wait for the city budget to add them or

[Marks]: uh, we voted to wait till the contract ended, which we all thought was too, at least I thought was 2020.

[Marks]: So knowing that, um, we're not gonna, if this doesn't end until 2023, um, that I'm asking now that we don't wait for anything and that the city administration.

[Marks]: add Maple Park condominiums, I believe it's 35 or 40 condos in there, add them to the bulk pickup, Mr. President.

[Marks]: That's all they're requesting.

[Marks]: There's a public list out there that shows you the different condos and what they receive as city services and waste management.

[Marks]: And it's my understanding the city just has to make a call to waste management and ask that this be done for Maple Park condominiums.

[Marks]: So I'd like to do that in the form of a motion, Mr. President, that the bulk pickup

[Marks]: be added immediately to Maple Park condominiums.

[Marks]: I don't remember seeing that, but if that's the case, that's great.

[Marks]: I don't think it's the case because the residents are still calling me.

[Marks]: They were actually asking me about the budget, if we're gonna put it in the budget, and that's why it precipitated this new resolution.

[Marks]: So that may be the case, but I don't know.

[Marks]: By request.

[Marks]: My understanding, it's by request.

[Marks]: That's my understanding.

[Marks]: I'm talking to DPW.

[Marks]: I was told by the condo association that at the time they were instructed by certain type of bins that were compatible with waste management.

[Marks]: And it would have been a great expense to them.

[Marks]: So they figured out rather than buy these new bins They already had bins that they would just bypass the service Now there it's I guess fruitful for them to participate and that's why they want to participate But I think at the time they had to get a certain bin and they weren't willing to do that to fit the you know compatible with waste management, but

[Marks]: These are all great questions, and I don't think we do have a formal approach once the contract is signed.

[Marks]: If condos would like to get back in, and they all pay taxes as was mentioned, they should have the ability to opt back in if they'd like.

[Marks]: So maybe that's something that could be explored by our DPW subcommittee.

[Marks]: In length of service, not age, by the way.

[Marks]: Mike Endicott, anyone that knows Lieutenant Mike Endicott, he is a tremendous firefighter, led by example, well liked among his peers, was the first to volunteer for anything going on in the community.

[Marks]: That was the type of firefighter Mike was.

[Marks]: He's a terrific husband, a great father.

[Marks]: a family man, and I wish him well, Mr. President, on his retirement and want to thank him on behalf of the residents of this community for the exemplary service for 32 years for the life and property of Method residents.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I had the opportunity to tune in last, I believe it was Thursday, the school committee had a meeting regarding concerns of budget.

[Marks]: And they had the city's auditor present, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I thought it was quite enlightening to hear some of the concerns on the school side.

[Marks]: But it was equally as stressful to hear that we're looking at potentially a 20% cut in local aid, which amounts to about a little over $5 million.

[Marks]: We are also looking at cuts in permits.

[Marks]: when I say cuts and permits, a reduction in permits close to $2 million.

[Marks]: Vehicle excise is down 7%.

[Marks]: Hotel and mails tax is down about a million dollar reduction.

[Marks]: Fixed costs are up, health insurance and unfunded liabilities.

[Marks]: And the list goes on, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Ultimately, I think what was stated, we're looking at a little over $8.2 million shortfall in the budget.

[Marks]: And depending on what happens this June 1st, they extended the deadline for taxes.

[Marks]: If we don't receive the full $29 million in taxes,

[Marks]: uh, which, uh, many people, uh, this community might be had press to send their taxes on time, uh, even with the extension, uh, that'll only add to our budget deficit gap.

[Marks]: Uh, so the 8 million could quickly grow, uh, to 10, 12, 14 million, Mr. President.

[Marks]: And I think as many Councilors are aware, our budget is probably about 85% salaries.

[Marks]: So when you look at tightening your belt, unfortunately, the belt tightening mostly is around personnel.

[Marks]: And that's where you can get into issues of furloughs and other options, days off and so forth, which I hope we never have to explore, Mr. President.

[Marks]: The one thing that was stated, and it was just stated briefly, we hear so much about the federal government bailing everyone out, right?

[Marks]: Um, and, uh, we have yet to receive, uh, any, uh, idea from the federal government, uh, about federal assistance, um, for a bailout of cities and towns that are really getting impacted by this COVID-19.

[Marks]: And, uh, in my opinion, we as a council should be soliciting or lobbying, uh, right now.

[Marks]: to make sure that whatever we experience in a budget gap is made up by the federal government.

[Marks]: And I think right now, I would ask that we send a letter from the council to our federal delegation

[Marks]: asking that the city of Medford, and I'm sure Dave is probably already in the process of doing this, but asking our federal delegation to assist us with a bailout, knowing that the state local aid is going to be cut, local receipts are down, taxes are probably going to be down, and fixed costs are up.

[Marks]: And our options right now, we do have about 10 million in free cash.

[Marks]: But as the mayor mentioned, we don't want to go through all our free cash because that leads us in a vulnerable position.

[Marks]: So even though we do have an ample amount of free cash, I think we have to look for just as that kind of a rainy day fund.

[Marks]: Um, so, um, there was some discussion during the school committee meeting and with the city auditor, uh, about what should we do with this year's budget that's coming up.

[Marks]: And I think one of the recommendations was a level funded budget makes most sense and most appropriate at this time, uh, knowing that there's probably going to be a shortfall and any additions to the budget, uh, is going to mean deletion somewhere.

[Marks]: Um, you know, not to say there's some good ideas floating out there that could be revenue generators, uh, or, uh, cost savings.

[Marks]: Um, and I think those should be explored, but I think a level funded budget right now, in my opinion, uh, makes sense, Mr. President with COVID and knowing that, uh, receipts are limited right now in the city and maybe that way for some time.

[Marks]: It's hard to put a finger on it right now.

[Marks]: So I just wanted to bring it up.

[Marks]: It's a majority vote, and that's the will of the school committee, which is then presented to the council.

[Marks]: I can't recall, I've been on a number of years, I can't recall ever the council cutting the school budget once it's submitted to us, ever.

[Marks]: Also, Mr. President, I can recall many times where this council has stood up and voted for new technology, school building assistance.

[Marks]: You name it, Mr. President, we've stepped up to the plate on numerous occasions.

[Marks]: So if there are concerns with the school budget that relies on the school committee, not the city council.

[Marks]: We're presented with their budget, Mr. President.

[Marks]: We can't add to it, Mr. President.

[Marks]: We can't do anything other than approving the total city budget.

[Marks]: And that's where we stand with this, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So for someone to stand forward and say, well, it's the council, that's being very disingenuous, Mr. President, because it's not the council.

[Marks]: It's the school committee that creates the budget and then passes it on to the council.

[Marks]: So if the school committee wishes to do other things, increase their budget, that's their prerogative.

[Marks]: That's their prerogative, and they should do so as elected officials in this community, as an autonomous body.

[Marks]: They're not tied to the council.

[Marks]: And that's where it is, Mr. President.

[Marks]: So I hope we can put this behind us and work forward, Mr. President, so we can address, as Councilor Knight and Councilor Caraviello and Councilor Scarpelli mentioned, so we can address all the needs of the community.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I want to thank Mr. Varnberg for bringing this issue up, because I know we've all been contacted by Medford residents that are equally as concerned.

[Marks]: I need to say over the last three or four weeks, this issue has evolved many times.

[Marks]: And I think originally, if we all remember, the issue was don't wear mask.

[Marks]: Remember when it first came out, they said mask won't help you.

[Marks]: And don't wear mask and leave the mask for the health care professionals.

[Marks]: the first responders, and then it evolved into, as more information came in, that it is helpful to have a mask and to reduce the risks like Councilor Bears mentioned.

[Marks]: I think there's a lot of misinformation out there that people believe if they, as long as they stay a social distance of six feet, in particular outside, there's no need for a mask.

[Marks]: And I think that's where a lot of the misinformation lies.

[Marks]: that now that has also evolved and your footprint, so called footprint is left behind.

[Marks]: And that's critical.

[Marks]: I just want to say to that mask is one aspect of PPE.

[Marks]: There's also gloves.

[Marks]: The disease is transmitted through droplets and so forth, but it's also transmitted through touch.

[Marks]: And you could be somewhere with a mask on, touch a surface, and then put that fingers to your eyes, to your nose, to your mouth after the fact.

[Marks]: and catch to the disease.

[Marks]: So if you don't protect your hands as well as your face, you're equally as vulnerable.

[Marks]: So whatever we do, I think we have to look at all aspects.

[Marks]: And in my opinion, I think it should be the wearing of gloves as well, the rubber gloves when you're out in public for now.

[Marks]: So I think education, as the chief of staff mentioned,

[Marks]: is extremely important.

[Marks]: The fact that Councilor Morell and Councilor Caraviello mentioned that not everyone, I had to make homemade face masks.

[Marks]: And it took quite some time to do it.

[Marks]: Everyone says, oh, look online, you make a quick, easy one.

[Marks]: They're not quick, easy, at least for me.

[Marks]: And I consider myself pretty handy.

[Marks]: They're not quick and easy.

[Marks]: And they don't fit right, they push your nose in, you can't breathe.

[Marks]: So there's a lot more than just making a quick homemade mask.

[Marks]: And I think if we can get these masks out to the general public, like was mentioned in Somerville and so forth, I think that'll go a long way for people that will have them near their front door, like I do.

[Marks]: Every time I go out, boom, it goes on automatically because it's right there.

[Marks]: But if I didn't have one in the house, who knows?

[Marks]: So I think the first thing for prevention is to make sure that these are out there.

[Marks]: And I don't know what we can do to get these masks and rubber gloves out there.

[Marks]: But I think that should be our first thing.

[Marks]: I don't like the concept of penalizing people, to be quite frank.

[Marks]: I know some communities of 200, 300 old fines for not wearing a mask.

[Marks]: I don't like that concept.

[Marks]: I think you have to get people to comply in a way that you reason with them and say, hey, you know what?

[Marks]: This is a concern for safety, concern for health.

[Marks]: Now we're hearing over in England and so forth that they're saying that kids are coming down with some sort of disease from the COVID that they didn't

[Marks]: think they were susceptible to.

[Marks]: This is brand new and they're starting to get cases over there.

[Marks]: You hear animals now, dogs, cats, you know.

[Marks]: So this is something that we really have to take the initiative.

[Marks]: I personally think it should be done through an executive order, because I think that's the way it should be initiated from the governor on down.

[Marks]: If the governor decides not to do it, then it's up to local cities and towns to take the responsibility.

[Marks]: So I'd like to see the mayor take, I know she's taken a lot of leadership on this, but I think the next logical step is to mandate that if you're out, that you should wear a mask.

[Marks]: And then if you're talking about enforcement, do we have the capability of enforcing it?

[Marks]: Probably not, but I think you'll see people comply.

[Marks]: if, you know, they're reasoned with and provided the mask.

[Marks]: So that's my two cents, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Mr. President, we do have Neil Osborne that's joining us and maybe he can give us just a brief overview of the census.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: For previous phases of the sidewalk improvements, this council has requested if the administration is working from a current list, if so, what percent of the list will be accomplished

[Marks]: through this 500,000.

[Marks]: So that was one of the questions that was asked in the past.

[Marks]: And I was asked that that be re-asked again, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Roughly how many sidewalks do they feel will be accomplished with this 500,000?

[Marks]: What priority, if there is an existing list, will the sidewalks be done?

[Marks]: Is there a priority list that is already established?

[Marks]: And when will the work

[Marks]: start to take place, assuming it's approved.

[Marks]: However, I mean, if you could do it either way, it doesn't matter to me.

[Marks]: Just if I could, because I know some of my other colleagues expressed concern.

[Marks]: Over the last several years, these particular requests for sidewalk repairs have been pretty consistent, as Council Vice President Caraviello mentioned.

[Marks]: And the consistent question back from the council has been, what is the list we're working from?

[Marks]: Because that's always been a moving target.

[Marks]: And I think members that have served for a number of years were never able to get a working list of what sidewalks are on the list.

[Marks]: Are they prioritized?

[Marks]: And then to accomplish some of the goals, I think, like Councilor Morell and Councilor Bears mentioned, is that when you hear phases, you assume that at some point this will be over, this phase one, phase two and phase three.

[Marks]: However, since I've been on the council, it's never had an end and there's never been an end game.

[Marks]: And I'm glad that we have a new administration now.

[Marks]: So I think these are important questions that we know what the list is, what is comprised of,

[Marks]: and what we're going to get for the money.

[Marks]: I realize we're in the second half of a contract, but that way it'll give us an understanding that, you know, after we do this phase, there's another phase, or this is the last phase, and then everything coming in will be new requests.

[Marks]: We've yet to get that over the years, and that's extremely vital so we can get a handle on it, like Councilor Scarpelli mentioned.

[Marks]: You know, we probably could have hired three, four, five people with equipment and a crew to do it internally and get much more bang for our buck by now.

[Marks]: However, we're at where we are right now, but I think moving forward, you know, I think we have to get these answers so we can make a financial decision that's good for this community and good for the taxpayers.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: And just one last point, if I could, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Yes, please.

[Marks]: Not to belabor this, but because when you talk sidewalks, most people think,

[Marks]: Oh, it's the replacement of a sidewalk panel.

[Marks]: But many times the work goes into curbing, goes into the removal of tree stumps because they may be the hindrance why you can't put a sidewalk and there may be a catch basin that's located near the sidewalk.

[Marks]: And that starts to expand the scope of the project.

[Marks]: And before you know it, rather than doing 500 panels or sidewalk panels, you're doing 50 with other related work.

[Marks]: These are the questions I think that we have to have answered.

[Marks]: And I know you can't tell sometimes until you get into a situation and say it involves much more than we anticipated.

[Marks]: But these are the type of things we have to know because 500,000 sounds like a lot, but when you start to do work, it doesn't go very far at all.

[Marks]: So I just want to put that out there.

[Marks]: While we have the Chief of Staff, have you looked at any other funding sources other than bonding?

[Marks]: Right, and we have what, at least four or five million in free cash or maybe even more?

[Marks]: And that decision's already been made.

[Marks]: Thank you.

[Marks]: Can you give us next time to just what we have out there for free cash?

[Marks]: Motion to table, Mr. President, until we get answers from the administration.

[Marks]: Until next week.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: I have a couple of questions.

[Marks]: First of all, how did the CPC arrive at this dollar amount?

[Marks]: So if I could, so it doesn't sound like you had any game plan.

[Marks]: When I say you, I don't mean you in particular, but it doesn't sound like there was a game plan on why 250,000 was selected.

[Marks]: I realize you had a half a million, but why was 250,000 selected?

[Marks]: Is it based on a number of families we believe that may be able to take advantage and that number would suit what we have the need for?

[Marks]: And the reason why I bring this up is from what I'm hearing is there's a potential that if we do prioritize method residents,

[Marks]: And just say that we overestimated the amount of need that could be out there.

[Marks]: And for instance, only $75,000 of Method residents came forward.

[Marks]: The other amount, according to what was stated, would have to go to other people that may be outside this community.

[Marks]: we can't withdraw the money, right, once our priorities of method families are done, say, okay, now we want to opt out of the program.

[Marks]: So, I'm just wondering how we arrived at that 250.

[Marks]: Mr. President, I also think it would be helpful maybe just to get an overview of eligibility requirements by the different programs.

[Marks]: And I think that would be very helpful.

[Marks]: And my last point is, will the full amount be used towards rental assistance or is there an administrative cost associated with this?

[Marks]: So that's a 10% administrative cost?

[Marks]: Yeah.

[Marks]: Okay.

[Marks]: And just what, what about basic eligibility?

[Marks]: But we just heard that's not a requirement.

[Marks]: You don't look at income, you don't look at anything.

[Marks]: So if they don't take part in stabilization, they can't take part of the program.

[Marks]: They were, and I just had one follow up if I could.

[Marks]: Sure.

[Marks]: Because we're talking one to 2,000, and I realize every case is different.

[Marks]: I realize that, and I realize there's all different circumstances and so forth.

[Marks]: But we're almost close to two months into this.

[Marks]: And from what I'm hearing, this could last another month or two.

[Marks]: And so you're potentially talking three, four, five months.

[Marks]: And when I hear $1,000 or $2,000, believe me, every little bit helps.

[Marks]: But rents in Method are no longer $1,000, $1,200.

[Marks]: They're $2,000, $2,500, $3,000.

[Marks]: And I'm just curious, if someone did lose their job or there's no income at all in the household, what is one or 2,000 going to do in a situation that you may need tens of thousands of dollars to keep someone going and functioning?

[Marks]: And, uh, are we underestimating this?

[Marks]: I'd hate to see this go to, uh, you know, I liked the more the merrier in my, in my opinion, I'd like to help out a vast number of people with the two 50, rather than just maybe a handful, uh, with the money.

[Marks]: So I'm just wondering how, how do we work this, uh, to make sure that we spread it out and knowing that, um, we're spread thin already because.

[Marks]: you know, $250,000 is not a lot to help a city of this size.

[Marks]: So I was just wondering if I could throw that out there.

[Marks]: Yeah, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Marks]: Um, the medallion program that he's talking about, uh, I'd like to see that implemented citywide where temporary and permanent patches utility company puts a small medallion with their name, uh, what they're doing there and contact information.

[Marks]: That way, anyone in the city, not just someone from the city engineer's office, can walk down their street and say, you know what, I see a sinking hole there.

[Marks]: It has the name of this particular company on it.

[Marks]: And then at least city hall knows what you're referring to and so forth and can get on top of it.

[Marks]: So I appreciate that work that Tim's done on that.

[Marks]: Tim mentioned about a capital plan.

[Marks]: This council has been calling for a capital plan for 20 years.

[Marks]: And I'm glad to hear that we will have a pavement capital plan because there's $0 allocated in the city's budget for total street repavement.

[Marks]: The money that we get for street repavement comes from chapter 90 money, which is about $980,000 a year.

[Marks]: And you're talking maybe if you can get through a street or two with that amount of money, you're lucky.

[Marks]: And we have over 760 streets in the city.

[Marks]: Uh, so you can see we're never going to get ahead of it by just following chapter 90 money.

[Marks]: We have to do some type of capital plan or put money on a yearly appropriation and the budget.

[Marks]: Um, you know, part of the frustration I think councilor Caraviello was talking about is every time a utility company appeared before the council.

[Marks]: The city engineer, and in this case it was the previous city engineer, would put all the agreements within the paper.

[Marks]: And you could bet your bottom dollar, it never said curb to curb restoration.

[Marks]: It was always permanent patch or restored as they found it.

[Marks]: And it was the council that took a stance back a year or two ago saying, you know what?

[Marks]: We're not going to tolerate this anymore.

[Marks]: We don't like the condition.

[Marks]: The subcontractors and utility companies are leaving our streets and we're going to require pavement curb to curb.

[Marks]: And many of them kicked back at us and we kicked back at them saying, well, maybe you won't get it approved if you're looking to get it approved.

[Marks]: And sure enough, each one over time committed to doing curb to curb restoration.

[Marks]: So part of the, uh, request, I think by councilor Caraviello myself, and I won't speak for him was to go back over the last year and a half, two years on all the council votes that requested curb to curb.

[Marks]: As a condition, not as just, Hey, will you please do this as a condition of approval, whether or not that got done.

[Marks]: And I realized it could be in the stages of getting done because Tim mentioned

[Marks]: It could be a temporary patch because there's other utility work being done there.

[Marks]: And that's fine.

[Marks]: There are a lot of other circumstances that play a factor.

[Marks]: I would personally like to know that my city engineer is backing what we think should be done.

[Marks]: And I think that would be the case.

[Marks]: So even if we create an ordinance that gave direction to the city engineer saying, this is how we would like to operate as a city and as a city council, knowing that you have to use your expertise and so forth and your judgment.

[Marks]: Uh, you know, I don't think you can create a cookie cutter.

[Marks]: We want curb to curb on every project.

[Marks]: Um, so I, I think we need to craft something.

[Marks]: that's meaningful that allows the city engineer to do his work and not tie his hands.

[Marks]: could have a potential impact on the investments that are being made.

[Marks]: bear holders.

[Marks]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Marks]: That's a very appropriate term, putting your money where your mouth is, because in fiscal 20 of last year, the taxpayers in this community invested $12.2 million into the retirement system to make that system whole.

[Marks]: the retirement system to make it whole.
